text:
I have made this several times now, and have found two main factors that make the difference between this being a 3* and a 5* meal. 1. Use at least 2 or 3 tortillas thick per layer. Otherwise, it gets soggy and mushy. 2. Let the meat simmer with the sauce at least 30 minutes, otherwise it does not meld together. This is a great recipe all in all, though, and I always look forward to making it. It is also a great freezer-to-oven meal. Simply take it out of the freezer and cook it at 350 for 40-50 minutes, or until bubbly. I always divide a full batch into several 11X7 pans, so I can freeze a couple for future meals. VERY IMPORTANT: I FREEZE IN A FOIL PAN...IF YOU FREEZE IN A GLASS PAN, YOU CAN'T PUT IT STRAIGHT INTO THE OVEN, OR ELSE THE GLASS WILL SHATTER. DEFROST IT FIRST.

text:
This recipe was good, but I know I will make several changes next time:  I too will use taco seasoning in the ground beef(no water), and I won't mix the beans in with the meat mixture - makes it too gloppy & all one texture.  I like the idea of spreading the beans on the tortillas, and will definitely use zesty beans.  The new layering order will be: meat, cheese, beany tortillas (bean side down), meat, cheese, beany tortillas etc.  I'm also going to split this into two 9" disposable pie pans - bake one & freeze the other for future use (this is a VERY big recipe). It was pretty good the original way, and I know we'll really like it this way.  Can't wait!

text:
Boy am I glad I didn't follow the advice of other reviewers to cut this recipe in half!  This was absolutely delicious!  Any easy, too!

This is the first recipe I've made in a LONG time where everyone at the table cleaned their plates - and asked for seconds (or thirds in my husband's case!).  With two young kids (3 and 5) this rarely happens (unless we're having hot dogs!) 

Using the same amounts of ingredients as called for in the recipe, I divided it up to make two different casseroles,  a spicier version for me and my husband and a mild version for the kids.  After browning the ground beef and onions, I divided the meat before adding the taco sauce.  I used medium sauce for the adult dish and mild for the kids.  For the adult dish I used all of the same ingredients as called for in the recipe (except olives).  For the kids, I just used tortillas, ground beef/onions/taco sauce, refried beans and cheese.  They loved it!  

Rather than mixing the refried beans into the beef mixture, I used a spoon to spread them on top of the tortillas before adding the beef mixture.  This worked very well and allowed me to adjust the amount to suit our tastes.  I ended up using about 1.5 cans between the two dishes.  

This will definitely become a regular in our house.  Thanks for a delicious, easy recipe that made dinner a very enjoyable occasion after a long day at work.  I can't wait to share the recipe with others.

text:
This deserves ten stars! Absolutely amazing dish. I made this when I was visiting my parents and it was a HUGE hit. None of us were expecting to be so crazy about it, but wow.

I'm trying to cut red meat out of my parents' diets, so I substituted the beef with turkey--without telling them (my dad wouldn't have tried it otherwise). I added some spices--cumin, season all, a couple of different kinds of pepper. I also did as others suggested and used one can black beans, one can spicy refried beans. I would up forgetting to add the taco seasoning, but it definitely wasn't missed.  Instead of taco sauce, I used chunky salsa. I served it with a handful of shredded lettuce, a couple of spoonfuls of fat free sour cream, and extra salsa on the top.

This made a nice sized casserole--I had to cut the tortillas to fit, though, because I bought the extra large ones and only had a...whatever the normal size cass. dish is. It's a very filling meal, and mom ended up freezing half of it, which she told me they plan on eating this coming week. There was *still* enough for us to have left overs the next day--it tasted just as good after a night in the fridge, by the way.

Fat free tortillas aren't your best bet for this, just fyi. I was hesitant about them, so I only used one in the middle, the rest were regular tortillas. Upon later inspection, the fat free tortilla kind of dissolved. So use fat free sour cream and use your fat grams for the cheese and tortillas. It's worth it!

It's a good weekend or Friday night dish.

text:
HELPFUL TIPS AFTER MAKING THIS FOR YEARS: Halve the MEAT but used 3/4th a can of the olives, whole can diced tomatoes & entire can of chiles (can't cut too much out or you won't be able to stack your pie).  Sometimes I add chopped red/green peppers and cut out onions. Eyeball the salsa (use enough to coat the meat) which I use instead of taco s.  Don't be afraid to layer this with 2-3 tortillas starting at the SECOND layer b/c it makes it taste just perfect (like taco bell mexican pizza)! I sprinkle taco seasoning over the beef while it's cooking (awesome flavoring) but not necessary.  It helps tremendously to let it simmer as long as it says because the ingred. start to stick together for a nicer consistency.  Apply a THIN layer of refried beans on the bottom of each new tortilla (i submitted pic), THIN layer of meat, & buy extra mexican cheese b/c you tend to use a lot to layer perfectly!  This made 3 thin layers of meat, cheese, refried beans w/just the right amount to add the last amount of meat on top & have enough refried beans to serve as a side (b/c you only use 1/4th of it).  If you make the full amount, it freezes well, so you can use it for a quick meal!  Update: I cook until edges of tortilla are not soft (almost crisp so never soggy) & people go nuts over this!

text:
This recipe calls for a "large skillet".  That is an understatement.  If you add all of the ingredients to the skillet, you will require a skillet of about 18-inches in diameter or a "rondo" (sp?).  Therefore, I did not add the refried beans to the pan.  Instead, I layered them onto the tortillas first, then the cheese, (which the recipe calls for 9 ounces but isn't quite enough, you need more like 12).  And, I still had 4 tortillas left over after I layered.  She also stated that a 4-quart casserole dish would suffice.  No way.  An 11"X 15" casserole pan is required to use all of the products.  The recipe also stated that it serves 7.  Seven what?? Giants??  I was able to get 12 servings from this recipe with leftovers.  If you want more "spice" than what the recipe states it has, add some jalapeno flavored refried beans instead of the basic and use a HOT taco sauce.  Overall, I'd say the author has a good recipe, but far from perfect.

text:
I made this recipe last night for dinner and it came out great. I halved the recipe and made it in a 9x13 inch pan. I cooked green onions instead of regular onions with the meat, the kids tolerate green onions. Instead of olives I added an 8 oz. can of mushrooms. I used a 7 oz. can of green chilies, we like them a lot. I used 1 whole can of diced tomatoes with green chilies, we like them a lot also. I used 8 oz. of homemade salsa, I always have some on hand, instead of taco sauce. I did use 1 whole can of refried beans, and we did not think it was too beany as other reviewers said. I used cheese to our liking, probably much more than called for. It was excellent! Thanks Kathi for a great, fast recipe!

text:
I'm only giving this one 4 stars because I modified it so heavily.  With the mods it was a 5.  Here's what I did.  First I scaled it in half and used a 13 x 9 pan.  I omitted the diced tomatoes and substituted 1/2 can tomato sauce since my kids aren't crazy about chunks of tomato.  I subbed my own fresh salsa but I think it would be fine with something like Pace.  I also squeezed in a bit of La Victoria red taco sauce for flavor.  I seasoned the meat mixture with 1 Tbsp. chili powder, 1 tsp. garlic powder, salt and lots of fresh ground pepper.  I used the whole can of green chiles (undrained).  I didn't mix in the refried beans or olives.  I sprayed the 13 x 9 pan with cooking spray and then put a very thin layer of meat mixture in the bottom of the pan.  Then I spread refried beans on 2 tortillas and placed them bean side down on top of the meat (overlapped they covered the bottom of the pan perfectly), more meat, cheese, olives.  I repeated this layer one more time ending with meat, cheese and olives on top.  I covered with foil and baked for 40 minutes.  Removed foil, topped with a bit more cheese and baked another 5 minutes.  It was REALLY good!  The main problem I heard from the previous reviewers was that the flour tortillas ended up soggy.  I believe this is because as written there is too much filling and it is too liquidy.  My tortillas were not the least bit soggy.  I will definitely make again with these mods.

text:
This is my 13 year old's favorite meal and we have it all the time. I do use kidney beans instead of refried bean, add a cup of frozen corn. I use taco seasoning and two cups of water. If you let it simmer long enough the water and seasoning cook right in. You do want some liquid in the filling because it absorbs into the tortillas. This is a huge recipe. I sometimes split it and freeze one of the dishes in a disposable metal pan. Cooks great from frozen. 90 minutes at 325 - uncovered the last half hour. Enjoy!

text:
I just made this recipe!  It was great.  Based on the prior reviews, I made a few changes:
*used a pack of taco seasoning to flavor ground beer (no onion/garlic)
*Mixed chunky salsa, corn, and diced green chilis in w/seasoned beef (I would prefer jalaps, but dh is a little wimpy when it comes to hot stuff)
*used a round casserole dish to layer, starting w/salsa, tortilla, meat, cheese, tortilla spread w/refried beans, etc
*halved the recipe and it fit perfectly in the casserole....could feed 4-8 depending on hunger and sides
*served w/sour cream

I'm always trying to eat healthier, so I used 97% lean ground beef, fat free refried beans, 2% cheese, and fat free sour cream and it was still very tasty!

country:
None
text:
I have made this twice now and both times it was a big hit. I did not use black olives or the chiles in tomatoes. I also used a Mexican blend of shredded cheese instead of Colby, 16 oz total, and black beans instead of refried.   I cooked the beef, drained any fat, added the onions, (1 time I omitted the garlic-didn't have any), cooked for 10 minutes. Then I added the chiles, 1 packet of taco mix, and 20 oz of Southwestern style salsa. I simmered for 15 minutes. I then put it together following a tip by another reviewer: crush the black beans and spread on tortilla. I layered starting with beef mixture, then cheese, then tortilla with beans (beans face down), and repeated. I ended the pie with a tortilla which I smothered with enchilada sauce and then the remaining shredded cheese. I used all mild ingredients. I served it with a side of sour cream. good stuff!!!!

None
text:
This recipe was really good! Wonderful taste! My husband loved it! I only changed a few things.
1) I used HOT enchilada sauce instead of taco sauce. Enchilada sauce is spicier than taco sauce and also has a better flavor.
2) I spiced up my meat to taste with some chili powder, paprika, cumin, and so on. 
3) I was worried that the flour tortillas might get mushy so here is what I did.  I took a skillet and sprayed it lightly with Pam. I then lightly browned my tortillas on both sides until they were crispy. This kept them from getting mushy or soggy while baking. This doesn't add to the prep time because I browned them while the meat mixture was simmering.

Also, I wanted to add that I had a pot luck party to attend the next day. I had to bring appetizers. I heated up some of the left overs and cut them into bite sizes. I then took some tostida scoop chips (the kind that look like little bowls) and filled them with some chopped lettuce, a scoop of the heated burrito pie leftovers, and topped them off with a small dollop of sour cream. I called them "mini taco salads" They were a hit!!

text:
OK, I read all these negative reviews before Making this.  To eliminate the "mushy" texture I didnt add refried beans to the mixture.  I simply bought two small cans of pinto beans, rinsed and cooked them with salt, pepper, garlic powder, and chili powder, and added the can of diced chiles with them, and a little water. Once boiling I smashed them and smeared them on the tortillas. I doubled the layer of tortillas so the tortillas wouldnt end up a mushy mess. I also used a cheesecake pan.  I added a lot of seasoning to the ground beef, like garlic powder, onion powder, oregano, chili powder, cumin. I drained the canned tomatoes well before adding.  I just added chopped jalapeno for heat when I was cookin the onion.  I added MORE cheese. In between the layers.  I mixed half a small can of enchilada sauce with half the bottle of taco sauce, BIG DIFFERENCE. i poured the taco sauce in the layers instead of mixing with the meat.  It came out way better this way, and we topped with sour cream, lettuce, and guacamole!!!

I thought this was wonderful!  I read a lot of the reviews before preparing this, and the number one complaint was that the meat wasn't spicey enough.  So I added a few beef bullion granuoles, a splash of red wine, some cayanne pepper, and about a half pkg of taco seasoning to the meat mixture.  I had no problems with soggy tortillas, I did overlap them.  Also, I used the mexican cheese, as I don't care for Colby.  THis was an easy and fab. meal that my husband loved and that I will prepare again soon!  I also thought it cut well.  I let it cool for about 10 minutes before cutting into it and it cut just like a lasagna.  Beautiful presentaion garnished with jalapenos and sour cream and a little extra salsa.  Served with chips to scoop up the extra filling! The leftovers were wonderful as well.  I thought about cutting the recipe in half and I am so glad I didn't.  Between 2 dinners and sharing with a few co-workers at lunch its all gone!  THanks for a great recipe!!

text:
The first time I made this I noticed that the flour tortillas were more trouble than they 
were worth. Didn't seem like they added a lot of flavor, either! I switched to corn tortillas, 
and it not only made the casserole easier to cut and serve, but added that corn zip to the
recipe. I also added some crushed red pepper, and used half the can of green chiles, but
added two minced Chipotle Peppers and about two tablespoons of the Adobo sauce from the 
can. Added a really smoky flavor to the dish, and raised the heat/flavor level a bit at the 
same time. We don't like olives, so we add more onions to make up for it! I also only use one
can of beans. Really good recipe, just needed some tweaking on the spices and the tortillas!

Made several times, we love it!  I half the recipe because it is plenty, and I make it in my springform pan and it fits perfectly!  After baking I always wait 15 minutes before removing the outer part of the pan and slicing.  It gives it time to settle and it is still hot.  I double the cheese, use 2 tortillas per layer(6 total), and use Original Rotel and medium taco sauce.  I have eliminated the extra chilis and olives because it tastes exactly the same without them and saves me a couple bucks. This recipe was great! My entire family loved it. My kids hate onions and tomatoes but didn't even notice they were in there. I made sure to chop the onions small and when I opened the can of tomatoes with green chilies I chopped those up too so the tomatoes wouldn't be so large. I only used one can of refried beans and I didn't add the can of green chilies because it also call for a can of tomatoes with green chilies and I though that was enough. I have never used Colby cheese before but it was much better than cheddar I am glad I bought that instead. So all in all I will be making this again and again. If you are looking for something new to try, TRY THIS ONE! It is easy and doesn't use a lot of dishes and everyone will eat it. That in itself is always a plus.

Very good! I used more than double the cheese called for. I only used 1 can of refried beans and combined it with the meat mixture. This is pretty ok; I doubt I'd make it again.  I relied on other reviewers' suggestions:  1) added a packet of taco seasoning (don't need to add water because the juices from other ingredients make it moist enough); 2) added a cup+ of frozen corn; 3) added extra green chiles cause I love them; 4) used white corn tortillas (personal fave); 5) spread the frijoles on the tortillas and then placed the tortillas, bean-side down on the cheese layers; 6) layered it meat/cheese/bean tortilla/repeat, then end with a meat layer followed by a cheese layer; 7) served with sour cream which was an excellent touch; 8) I also cut the recipe in half (for 8 servings) and it all fit in a 9x9 glass baking dish.  Think that's it.  It's a casserole-y meal; so nothing out-of-this-world but fit the bill for a Cinco de Mayo night for the neighborhood potluck.

There are so many reviews on this recipe, does it need one more?  Well, here goes.....I would agree on the following:  very heavy, makes a huge quantity (I used a stock pot to make mine!) and not a lot of texture.  However, it is a lot like a burrito!  I made many changes per other recommendations.  1)  1/2 refried beans, 1/2 black beans.  2)  salsa instead of taco sauce.  3)  added lots of spices (some reviewers added taco seasoning, but I prefer to use my own seasoning) like cumin, chili powder, and oregano.  All in all, this is the kind of recipe that is a launching pad for your imagination and personal taste.  Have fun and be creative!

text:
So good!  My family loved this.  It was a great alternative to an expensive visit to the local Mexican restaurant, and was quick enough to prepare after an afternoon of soccer practice.  I added a packet of burrito seasoning to the ground beef and followed the suggestion to spread the refried beans on the tortillas rather than adding them into the beef mixture.  I used fat free refried beans.  For the tortilla layers, I placed one layer of bean-coated tortillas, bean side down, and topped with a second layer of plain tortillas.  I placed the sliced olives on top of half of the casserole and omitted the olives from the other half (picky kids).  Everyone seemed to enjoy this topped with fat free sour cream.  Great recipe!

I've saved the meat mixture part of the recipe in my files for future use. This will replace my current burrito recipe for sure!

text:
This is an absolutley delicious dish! I have made this twice so far, and everyone who has tried this, loved it. I prefer to use a deep 9x13 inch disposable aluminum pan for this. I make the meat filling exactly as written, but I use a few more tortillas per layer, and I also use more cheese, because we love it! I found that using a shredded seasoned Mexican blend cheese adds wonderful flavor also. I serve this on a bed of shredded iceberg lettuce, with a side of guacamole and top with salsa and sour cream. If your prefer a lot of heat, layer some sliced jalapeno peppers between the layers. This really is a fantastic recipe, and it's easy. I will definitely make this again and again! Thanks for posting :)

text:
I can't say enough about this recipe, especially if you love burritos like I do...but can never quite get them wrapped right!  I cut the recipe in half, and still had half a dish left over!  I used a round deep dish casserole, which the tortillas fit in perfectly.  I only changed the recipe to make a healthier version, but honestly you don't lose any of the taste!  I used ground turkey, whole wheat tortillas, fat free re-fried beans, and reduced fat cheese and sour cream.  I did follow other reviews advice and added taco seasoning to the meat along with a little ground cumin.  Instead of the can of tomatoes, I used a homemade Mexican chunky style salsa and a homemade black bean and corn salsa to add into the meat mixture.  I also did not mix the re-fried beans as another review suggested, I spread the re-fried beans onto the tortilla and placed that over the meat mixture!  I usually never go for seconds, but with this, I couldn't help myself!

text:
Good Stuff!  I actually made this recipe close to the way it was written which is unusual for me.  I did add a can of chopped tomatoes because they are so good for you.  I used jalapeno refried beans, medium hot taco sauce and a 7 oz can of green chilis.  It was spicy but I am from Texas so that was just fine!  I think next time I will use one 8 oz bottle of taco sauce and one packet of taco seasoning with a larger can of tomatoes to make up some of the liquid I would be missing.  It was a little vinegary tasting due to the taco sauce, which was a premium brand.  I loved the way this wasn't too wet and stayed in portions so nicely.  It would make a great potluck and you could add the lettuce and tomato right on top with little "kisses" of sour cream on each portion.  Nice and easy.  Great recipe!

text:
This was tasty and filling. There are so many reviews on here you just don't know what to believe. I am watching my calories constantly, so figured I would try to make it without doubling up on tortillas as others suggested. They weren't soggy at all. In fact, I only used 9 flour tortillas - three per layer. I also only used 1 lb of beef and 1 can of refried beans - also perfectly fine. I used salsa instead of taco sauce, and 2% cheddar cheese. These changes basically halved the recipe and it made 8 servings in a 9x13. Will make again!

text:
This is a big hit at my house.  I half the recipe and make it with fajita sized tortillas in a round, 2L casserole dish then cut it like pie wedges over shredded lettuce.  Following some other's suggestions, I brown the tortillas in a skillet while the mixture is cooking so that they don't disintigrate while baking.  Also, for half the recipe, I use a whole can of Rotel and leave out the chilis and olives. Also replace the taco sauce with chunky mild salsa and add most of a packet of taco seasoning and some cumin and it's plenty spicy for my house.    I use low fat tortillas and fat free cheddar instead of the colby, as well as 4% fat ground beef and fat free refried beans and it comes out great and fits very well into our diet.

I was really disappointed with this recipe. The only flavor that comes through is the green chili peppers...very one-dimensional. If I were to make this recipe again, I would substitute (1) spicy enchilada sauce for the taco sauce, and (2) black beans for the refried beans (oh, why didn't I take the advice of reviewers?!). My teenaged son, who loves Mexican food, thought this recipe was horrible. One final note: I will concede that one's results with this recipe probably depends upon what taco sauce and refried beans one uses, since both items come in a variety of styles/flavors.

Thanks for a wonderful and easy recipe! I added a TBS of salt (personal preference), i also used a can of black beans in place of one of the refried beans (make sure to drain them well). after tasting it while cooking i decided to add 1/2 ts of cumin and also half a small package of taco seasoning. text:
I make a version very similar to this, but with these adjustments:
Add taco seasoning to the ground beef when cooking (cumin, chili powder, garlic & onion powders, salt & pepper) to taste. Leave out the taco sauce. I always put the flour tortillas in a pan on the stove and crisp them up just a bit to avoid the sogginess. I top mine with cheese and crunched up tortilla chips and bake. When done, I serve with salsa, sour cream and avocado slices. It is always a hit this way!

Review:
Rating:

userID:
7546439
Display Name:
spittykitty
isPro:
False
followersCount:

86

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/824245.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This one is a winner - tastes great and everyone cleaned their plates.  None of us thought this was very hot/spicy, but it does have a very good flavor - next time I'll add diced jalapenos instead of diced green chilis to give it more kick. Followed the recipe very closely except I always add more garlic and I used a large 6oz can of sliced black olives and saved some to put on the top layer.  I was concerned about the meat mixture being too runny, so I simmered it until most of the juices were reduced.  I also didn't mix the refried beans with the meat - warmed them separately and added a little of the taco sauce to thin it a bit.  I used a 3qt rectangular Corningware casserole dish and trimmed large tortillas to fit. Made the tortilla layers only 1 thick even though some reviewers suggested using 2 or three per layer.  Glad I did - it wasn't too runny at all and I didn't want to add extra carbs.  Spread warmed refried beans on the tortilla layer, then added a layer of the meat mixture, then a layer of cheese - repeated 3 times until all ingredients were used up.  Cooked it longer than the recipe called for - about 45 minutes so the top would brown.  Then let it stand about 20-30 minutes before serving it so it would set.  Served with sour cream and green onions.  I will definitely be making this one again.

text:
I made this for dinner last night and it was so good. I followed some reviewers suggestions, only using one can of refried beans and one can of black beans. I cooked the black beans with the meat mixture, but reserved the refried and spread them on the bottoms of the tortillas while I was layering. Since it's just 2 of us, I split this into two pans, and froze one for later. I also ended up adding some taco seasoning and enchilada sauce because I felt like the meat was missing something. Overall, really good dinner, and probably something we will make again. We liked it with some shredded lettuce and sour cream on top.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/154.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is sooooo good.  I used a 5-quart 11x15 pyrex dish to bake it in.  I mixed spicy and regular refried beans together and left them separate to layer with instead of adding to the meat mixture.  I also added the black beans separate.  I cooked the meat mixture with an envelope of taco seasoning because I wanted it spicy but did not add any water.  I first poured about a cup of the meat mixture in the baking dish sprayed with Pam.  Then staggered 3 burrito size flour shells on that.  Then I spread 1/3 of the refried beans, then sprinkled 1/3 of the black beans, then sprinkled with 1/3 the cheese, then the meat mixture again till I had 3 layers.  I topped the whole thing off with a little more cheese before baking.  My husband and son have not stopped raving about this recipe!!!!  I served it with lots of chopped green onion, sour cream, and extra taco sauce.  What luck finding this fabulous recipe!  Thank you!

text:
i have some very slight variations of this recipe. I use the super size yellow or white corn tortillas. I make my own refried beans (hate the can kind) and i spread the beans on the tortillas (like i would peanut butter)instead of mixing it with the meat and i sprinkle the olives on top of the casserole. sometimes i put shredded lettuce, sour cream (the mexican 'creme' kind) and tomatoes on top after it's done cooking. kids and grown ups always love it :)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this last night.  After reading many reviews, I made the following changes.  I added in one packet of taco seasoning to the browned meat (I used ground turkey).  I didn't put the refried beans in with the meat mixture, but instead spread them on top of the tortillas.  I could only find packages of 8 count tortilaas so I cut each in half and doubled up on the tortillas when layering to prevent them from getting soggy.  I used an 11x17 baking dish and layered it:  meat, cheese, beany tortillas...meat, cheese, beany tortillas...topped with more shredded cheese.  I covered and baked for 30 minutes, then uncovered and baked another 7 minutes.  Let it rest for 10 minutes and served with salsa and sour cream on the side.  Was delicious and tasted even better today.

I saw this recipe and used it for a PTO teachers dinner.  I kept my fingers crossed as I hadnt tried it before taking it into the teachers.  It was a HUGE hit!  I made it again for a birthday and even froze one and brought it out a week later and it was fabulous.  By placing them in a round cake pan, it fits perfectly! Getting ready to make it for a friend who just came out of surgery as I know it will freeze well and she can cook it at any time.   
I too spread the refired beans on the wraps and placed them "bean side down" instead of mixing it in with the meat.    I plan on adding some mexican corn the next time I make it to brighten the color.   Great for a crowd, you can make it ahead of time and just throw it in the oven when the guest arrive.    ENJOY!

text:
The first two times I made this, it came out 5-star delicious. The third time I made it, I decided to make it the day before, as others suggested. Don't make it ahead unless you absolutely have to. It's not near as good. There were three things I didn't like when doing it this way. 1) Because you're starting with a cold pie, the cheese started to get too brown on top without it getting completely heated through the middle. 2) I did not like the texture of the tortillas as well. 3) The bottom tortillas stuck.

text:
I thought this was really great!  I did change a few things based on the suggestions from other reviewers.  I added a packet of taco seasoning to the hamburger mixture and about 1/2 cup of water.  I let it reduce until it was thick.  I also spread the refried beans on the tortillas instead of mixing them with the hamburger.  Definitely put in two tortillas per layer instead of one.  It was just the right consistency and wasn't mushy.  I made in a 10" springform pan that was the exact size of the tortillas I used so it worked perfectly.  Really good and it made a ton.  I would definitely recommend this recipe and just adjust to your taste.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
You absolutely must taste the meat mixture while cooking it. It tasted pretty bland, so we added 2 envelopes of taco seasoning and prob.about a teaspoon of salt. I also toasted the tortillas in a dry skillet as suggested, and spread the beans on the tortillas instead of adding to the mixture. Oh, I also added several dashes of Tabasco, and chipotle dry seasoning. I also used diced tomatoes with jalapeno (Del Monte brand, I think). Excellent recipe--feel free to tweak it to make it your own. And yes, it did make a lot of food. I filled one 9x13 as well as a 9" pie plate.

This was a great recipe with a few modifications.  I omitted the olives and spiced up the beef with cumin, adobo and chili powder.  I also used corn tortillas instead of flour tortillas with a little oil on the bottom of the pan.  I then used cooked rice to layer in also and added some fresh cilantro.  It was then topped off with fresh salsa.  WONDERFUL!  Then entire family was well pleased and is fighting over the left overs!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This came out great!  I omitted the olives (hubbie doesn't like them,took the suggestions of other reviewers and made the following alterations-

(1) Use 1/2 refried and 1/2 black beans 
    (drained)
(2) Add canned corn (drained)
(3) Add taco seasoning to meat(don't  
    add water)
(4) Substitute salsa (I used 505  
    southwestern salsa w/ flame roasted 
    New Mexican green chile)
(5) Don't mix beans with meat
(6) Layer refried beans, meat, black   
    beans, cheese, corn, repeat 
(7) Fry tortillas b/f baking (no need 
    to double layer if you do this)

Serve with sour cream, cheese, avocado (opt), and salsa

* wrap leftovers in new tortilla for   
  lunch

text:
This made an easy and tasty supper and even my picky husband liked it. I scaled the recipe by half since it originally made such a large quantity. Because of this, instead of using taco sauce and tomatoes, I used a 14.5 oz can of plain diced tomatoes (in my household even MILD Rotel tomatoes it too spicy) and seasoned the ground beef with a packet of taco seasoning. I wasn't sure how thick to spread the filling and ended up only using 4 tortillas before running out of filling and cheese but it would have been better if I'd managed all 6 called for. My husband said he thought he'd like the filling rolled up inside of the tortillas like regular burritos also.

Yum!  I added 1/2 package of taco seasoning to the meat along with the garlic and onion.  I used 8 oz of taco sauce and a mixture of Mexican cheeses. text:
my family loved this recipe. I took some ideas from others--- such as I added a bag of frozen corn, I fried the taco shells in vegetable oil--- to try to make them harder, but it didn't make a big difference (and I probably won't do it again because it's such a waste.) I did find that the meat was a bit bland-- so I added 2 packs of taco seasoning and no water. I used salsa instead of taco sauce and kept it seperate--- as a layer close to the top. I added a lot more cheese... but we are cheese people! We've had it twice now, and I would highly reccommend it. It is a HUGE portion. It feeds my family of 6 twice with left overs.

text:
What an excellent idea: lasagna with a Mexican twist.  We liked this when it was hot out of the oven, but I heated it up in the microwave the next day and it was OUTSTANDING.  The flavors blend and the individual layers take shape overnight in the fridge.  I added a layer of cream cheese and regular cheese on the inside.  I also used a mexican cheese mix instead of just colby.  This recipe makes a TON.  Now we have tons of leftovers to savor!!!! YUM. Note: be sure to use a double layer of tortillas each time you use them.  It holds up better and the taste is excellent.

userID:

Display Name:
Megan Tracy
isPro:

followersCount:

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2228099.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe with a few tweeks based solely on my family's like's. I used two pounds of ground pork. While cooking, I seasoned the meat with Lawry's Seasoning salt, garlic powder and minced onion. In a separate pan I fried up one link of chorizo (Mexican sausage) and added that to two cans of authentic refried beans. In a baking dish I layered meat first, burrito sized tortillas, beans, then cheese. I repeated this until the pan was full. My top layer I added black olives, green onions and a jar of Herdez mild salsa. I used the same temp and baking time. I also had Mexican crumble cheese as well. Enjoy!

text:
This was really good. Everyone in the house ate it, well most. A couple of us are new vegetarians. :) However, my kids are usually very bland eaters with regards to chilies, tomatoes and the such. But this went over well. I subbed ground turkey because we don't do beef, and did extra basic seasonings pepper and cumin on meat. Didn't add granulated garlic or dried minced onion, as the recipe already had fresh. I also used taco seasoning with the liquid from the tomatoes to simmer in and I think that helped with any sogginess problems that could have happened had I used taco sauce. Didn't have to double layer tortillas or anything. Did refried beans as its own layer. Kept olives out and people added as they wanted, along with shredded lettuce and sour cream. Will definitely be making again. Thank you!

text:
I made this recipe before and while it was good, I tried it again with some of the suggestions from other reviews and it was fantastic!

Even still, the modifications were pretty minor:
- double the thickness of the tortilla layers
- spread the beans over the tortillas (do not mix them in the sauce)
- simmer the sauce longer, about 30 minutes
- add extra seasoning to taste, to the sauce mixture...chili powder, ground cumin, salt, pepper and extra garlic if needed

Made it for a potluck. Yummy!

text:
I made the recipe almost exactly as written.  The only change was I added my homemade taco seasoning to the meat when I cooked it.  I didn't expect a whole lot going into this recipe.  Quite frankly, I am a food snob and whole food purist at heart and any recipe that uses jars and cans kind of makes me cringe.  BUT, my family loves Mexican food and we desperately needed a break from the same old dishes I was making.  I had a killer craving for some burrito style food so I took a chance and thought, "one meal from jars and cans won't be that bad".  What a mistake!  My family LOVED this.  My husband and three kids 13, 11, 10 went burrito pie crazy.  We almost had a riot start over the last two pieces.  My husband asked me to make it again three days later.  So needless to say this recipe has single handedly adulterated my whole food fed soul. So I feel I must warn others who may be mindlessly browsing through recipes and feel the supernatural tug of burrito pie power pulling them towards the endless pit of cravings it brings.  Save yourselves!  It is too late for my family but for burrito's sake, save yourselves!

text:
Delicious! I have been wanting to try this recipe for a while now and am so glad I did! Very easy to put together and great flavor for a one pan meal. I did alter it a bit though to what I had on hand. I had no taco sauce so I used a can of enchilada sauce with a bit of taco seasoning mixed in. And as our family isnt crazy about all things spicy I left out the chiles. I didn't have tortillas so I made the homemade flour tortillas from this web-site and it was a family hit! I halved the recipe and used two tortillas per layer. Fit perfectly into a 9X13 pan. I let everything simmer for about 30 min. And spread the warm refried beans on the tortillas in their own layer instead if mixing into the meat mixture. I did meat on the very bottom like stated, then tortilla, beans, meat, cheese, etc. So yummy! A keeper for sure. Cant wait to make again!

text:
I made this last night for the first time!  I was pleasantly surprised at how much it makes! (I should have had a clue with the ingredient list!!) But, I am glad I didn't read the reviews first or I may have been tempted to make changes that certainly weren't necessary! I tried cutting some fat by using fat free refried beans and substituting ground turkey for half the meat and using lean ground beef for the other half.  All the flavors meld together well, and I found no other seasoning was necessary!  Plenty of flavor in the bottle of taco sauce it calls for. My casserole dish was a little wider than the tortillas so I cut and pieced a little and it worked fine. I actually made one large and one smaller casserole. This heats up wonderfully the next day and doesn't need anything extra.  I am sure you can add all kinds of toppings, lettuce, tomatoes, sour cream, avocado. But it doesn't need it.  I did use more cheese, since I like it and so I just used what I felt looked good.
All in all, I made it exactly as written.  My girls loved it!  Next time I will either half the recipe or invite more people to dinner!

text:
Great recipe!  As for freezing and then baking, if you use a glass pan, just line it with foil first, then when fully frozen, remove from the glass pan, wrap thoroughly and you won't have the issue with baking in a cold glass baking dish.  You can also put your cold glass baking dish in the cold oven and let it preheat along with the oven gradually and it won't crack.

userID:
4014136
Display Name:
gayla
isPro:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow, I am happily surprised that my dinner turned out so tasty.  Funny thing to say that you didn't really expect a dish you invested money and time into making would be great, but that's the truth.  I made this because I wanted to use up some canned goods that were close to expiration and leftovers.  So, here's what I did:  Defrosted 1.5 lb already browned ground beef in the microwave and then cooked it for a while with about 2 cloves of garlic and the remainder of a red onion (probably 3/4) left in the fridge.  Then dumped one can of refried beans, a 4oz can of Hatch chiles, a LARGE can (28 oz I think) of green chile enchilada sauce, taco seasoning packet, a tablespoon or so of cumin, a tablespoon of chile powder, a tablespoon of ground cayenne (I like spicy.) and a teaspoon or so of chipotle chile powder.  (Wish I'd used even more cayenne.)  Cooked all of this about 25 minutes to let the flavors meld.  Meanwhile, I chopped up black olives, gathered the remainder of a bag of shredded Mexican cheese, a baggy of leftover Cotija cheese and the corn tortillas in my fridge that also had to be used or tossed.   Spread some of the meat mixture on the bottom and then a doubled layer of crisped tortillas, more meat, Mexican cheese mix, Cotija cheese, black olives and jalapeno slices.  Repeated this about 2 more times, ending with more tortillas with cheese, olives and chopped green onions on top.  Cooked about 30 minutes at 375.  Delish and used everything up I intended. :)

userID:

Display Name:
Colscook

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677173.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I think that this recipe was really good. My husband kept saying this is good and eating more! A few changes based on comments on the site. Added 1 package of taco seasoning to the meat. Next time I will use turkey instead. Used regular diced tomatoes - 14 oz can. Used salsa instead of taco sause- I'd recommend mild salsa. I used medium and that gives quite a kick. Used 1 can refried beans and 1 can hot chili beans. spread the refried beans on the tortillas and then layered the beans with the meat and cheese.  Used whole wheat tortillas, low fat cheddar cheese. After cooking I put sliced avacado, shredded lettuce and some non-fat sour cream on top . The toppings add a lot in my opinion so don't omit. 
The other issue I had was that it seemed like there was too much liquid so I drained some off. DON't DO THAT! You will need it as the liquid gets absorbed into the tortillas. 
This makes two 11x 7 ( 2 quart ) casseroles. Freeze one and enjoy later! I will definately make this again!

text:
This was so easy, but made a TON! I followed other suggestions and let the sauce simmer longer, also used 3 tortilla per layer. One big thing to note here, in the instructions it says to use a "large skillet" this is fine for the hamburger/onion/garlic, once you add everything else there is no way it will fit in a skillet. I used a large pot. Maybe if the recipe is halved it might fit in a large skillet, but I would recommend combining like chili to simmer in a pot.

text:
I cut the recipe down to 4 servings.  Scaling it down I still used more beans and olives than called for, because I like them!  I used 4 large 100-calorie tortillas and cut them into 4ths so they would fit in my dish.  I added taco seasoning (minus water) to the meat then browned it.  I did not mix the beans into the meat mixture, but instead spread them on the tortillas.  I ended up with 4 layers.  I baked it covered at 350 for 30 minutes.  I uncovered it and added more cheese to the top and baked uncovered for 5 more minutes, until melted.  Super yummy!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2011-10-13T10:55:20.613

I topped the meat mixture with sour cream and medium cheddar cheese before doing another layer. This recipe was a HUGE hit my husband even brought it to work and had people try it. :)

text:
I thought this was very good. It was well seasoned, but per other reviews, I added Taco Seasoning I (by Bill Echols on this site) to the meat. I also used homemade taco sauce. This was very well spiced. I do agree with others who did not prefer the re-fried beans. Next time I will use only whole beans. I made a couple of additions: 1 pastilla pepper, and 1 cup of sweet frozen corn (adds a nice sweet crunch). I didn't add the green chilies because I didn't have any, and I used regular diced tomatoes (in pantry) More cheese would be an improvement. Thank you for sharing your wonderful recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is fantastic - but a few modifications are necessary, otherwise the layers aren't very defined.  Instead of mixing the beans, it works best if they are spread on the tortillas and then layered with the meat mixture.  Also, I use taco seasoning instead of taco sauce.  With the sauce, the meat mixture is a little to soupy, and makes the whole dish a little soggy.  We use corn tortillas (double layer) instead of flour and add jalepenos to the mixture, but that's just personal preference.  My husband always eats 3 helpings, and if there are any - the leftovers are fabulous the next day!

text:
This was delicious and very filling!!  Made a few changes - used 1.5 cans of refried beans, as well as 1/2 a can of black beans and 1/2 can of corn.  Also used whole grain tortillas (from Trader Joes) and doubling up on them worked really well.  Made the recipe very mild - no chilles and no olives (I hate them). Overall, this was very good, and my hubby requested that I make it again  :)

Display Name:
merhope1011

None
text:
SUPER YUMMY! My husband is allergic to beans, legumes, & soy so at 1st glance this recipe would either not work for us as a family or would be kinda boring if we just omitted the beans. B/c of his allergy, we eat some sort of meat w/almost every evening meal. Needless to say, it gets pricey. I wanted to start adding beans into my son's diet more & try to save a little $ so I started out w/this recipe. I 1/2-ed all the 'filling' ingredients (subbed salsa for taco sauce; couldn't find organic taco sauce anywhere!), left out the beans & cooked that in one pot. In another pot, I made homemade refried pintos (beans, salt, water) (SO much cheaper & IMHO SO much yummier!) & added the other 1/2 of the 'filling' ingredients to it (saute onion 1st) (& using only 1/4 of the jar of salsa b/c my son & I don't really care for super spicy things) & left out the peppers & olives too. As I was getting the beans ready, I felt bad for my husband - they were so yummy & creamy & his filling was so... ground beef-looking. LOL So, I added about a cup of sour cream, thinking it would thicken it up. WRONG! It was SO watery! So I removed some of the watery-ness & mixed it w/corn starch, stirred it back in, cooked it up again, & voila - creamy. I used two square glass baking dishes w/the meat filling in one & the bean filling in the other. I used 6 tortillas total (2 layers for each dish) & just tore them into pieces to cover the filling/cheese. If you are vegetarian or allergic to beans HTH!!

Display Name:
liesh

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm giving it a four as written, but some tweaking will definately make it a five. To start I used a non-stick 2" high 9" springform pan. My recipe ends up being medium not hot, but adding a can of jalapenos instead of green chili's will take care of that. One can of refried beans is plenty, but don't add them to the meat mixture. I browned the beef with a little salt then added 1 can of enchilada sauce, one can of tomato sauce, one jar of hot salsa,and 1/2 tsp of chili powder, garlic powder, and cumin. I used whole grain tortillas which hold up much better and don't mush out, and with all the sauce no one will ever know.  If you use a non stick pan don't spray the bottom. Starting from the bottom the layers go...tortilla, pepperjack cheese onion and chili's, tortilla, meat sauce, tortilla with beans placed bean side down on meat, cheddar cheese, onions, and chili's, tortilla, meat sauce, tortilla with beans side on meat, pepper jack cheese onions and chili's, torilla, meat sauce, tortilla with bean side on meat, and finish off with cheddar on top. Bake for about 30 min. until the cheese is brown and bubbly, and let it sit for at least 30 min before releasing the pan sides it needs to cool in order to set well. served with sour cream on the side. DELISH.

Display Name:
DELKEE

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe gets a 4 because it's an inspiration for an improved customized version.

I made three changes:  I used ground turkey instead of beef and I omitted the olives.  I also did not mix the refried beans in with the meat, but instead used them as a separate layer.

I cut this recipe in half since we are a household of 2 and it made more than enough for dinner and lunch the following day.  This is a great starter recipe, but I will make changes in the future.

First, it was not spicy enough for my taste.  Second, the use of taco sauce and diced tomatoes made the casserole taste suspciously like lasagna, not what I want in a Mexican-inspired dish.  I will use enchilada sauce, taco seasoning, and fresh jalapenos in the future to avoid that tomato-y Italian flavor.

On the positive side, the texture is beautiful, it slices easily, and the refried beans are really great in this dish.  The consistency reminds me of a bean burrito.  The only thing I didn't like about the presentation of this dish is that the cheese never bubbled and shined.

Overall, this is a good family recipe that needs more spice and less tomato-y flavor.

text:
Both my picky sister and husband loved this.  I took the advice of others and added a packet of taco seasoning, but next time I'll probably only do half a package as it overpowered the dish a bit and became more of a "taco pie."  Served it with sour cream and it was delicious!

I used 3 tortillas per layer and I let it rest for about 10 minutes before trying to slice it up.  I think that helped because we didn't have the soupy mess some people seem to have had.  We probably could have just used 2 tortillas per layer.

text:
I followed the recommendation of others and doubled each layer of tortilla and served this on shredded lettuce.  I found that when we went back for seconds, the meal tasted a little better the second time around (it wasn't as 'wet' and held together much better).  I think that next time I'll allow the Burrito Pie to sit for 20 or so minutes before serving.  

My husband had leftovers at work and emailed me to tell me how great it tasted!  I'll definitely make this dish again!

text:
Fantastic! My whole house smelled like our favorite Mexican restaurant!  I agree with Taylor..I cut the recipe in half as well and it STILL made more than enough! Hopefully, it will freeze well.  A couple of "serve with" suggestions.  I made homemade quacomole ('course you can buy it too!), salsa, sour cream, green onions (scallions ~ for garnish) and corn chips.  Sort of a big "fiesta"! I didn't change any of the ingredients...we love olives .    When choosing the sauces, chiles, etc. you can opt for hotter varieties (to those of you who thought there wasn't enough flavor/spice) or, as was suggested, add hot pepper sauce, cumin..whatever.  We loved it and it's a keeper! Thanks for sharing!

text:
I love this recipe and have made it many times. I add taco seasoning to the beef for added flavor and use low-carb tortillas instead of regular flour ones. I omit the olives and top with sour cream and salsa.  Follow the directions and combine the refried beans to the meat mixture in the pan before you spread it in the dish.  It saves time (instead of layering the beans and meat seperately) and tastes the same either way after cooking! Burrito Pie is well worth the five star rating!

text:
Very good, tasted like a wet burrito.  I would have rather used the filling to MAKE actual wet burritos though.  Also, FYI for anyone who does make this lasagna style.  You might want to consider putting 2 layers of tortillas when you layer them, one layer seemed to bake into the filling and become too mushy.  The photo of it, HAS to be more than one layer of tortilla, or else they are just VERY thick!

text:
My family LOVES this recipe!  I incorporated some of the previous reviewers' suggestions.  I added our favorite Taco Bell seasoning to the meat (sans the water)and also pulsed the meat in a food processor before adding the olives, chilis, tomatoes w/ chilis and salsa.  I spread spicy refried bean on the tortillas; used jalapenos in place of the green chilis and canned tomatoes with jalapenos as well.  I halved the recipe and baked it in a 9" cake pan (perfect!) because I wasn't sure how the leftovers would be.  The leftovers were even better, so I'll make the full recipe next time.  Thanks for sharing Kathi.

OK first off, i half this recipe.  Sometimes i vary taco sauce with salsa.  I use chedder cheese cause thats what i have onhand.  Overall a very versitle recipe you can play with, try using enchilada sauce instead of taco sauce for a different flavor.  I have been using this recipe as a base for years, it is one of my husband's most asked for meals.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2003-07-31T10:56:33.687
helpfulCount:
3
userID:
574240
Display Name:
CTCOOK
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The whole family enjoyed this.  It looks good and cuts great if you let it stand 10 minutes or so before serving.  Even better the next day.  I reviewed other's suggestions before making this and decided to add 1/2 tsp. cumin and 2 tsp. mexican oregano to the meat mixture. (After trying it this way I think adding an entire envelope of taco seasoning, as other reviewers suggested would be unnecessary and also too salty, the flavor is already in there.) I also used an entire 6 oz. can of olives because we really like them.  Instead of 10 oz. rotel tomatoes I used a 16 oz. can of Del Monte petite cut tomatoes with jalapeno peppers.  I used mild taco sauce to make it kid friendly and the end result was flavorful but not hot at all.  Those who like heat will want to use medium or hot taco sauce.  I did replace one can of refried beans with 1 can black beans.  Gave it nice texture and color.  I did not have to cut the recipe in half to make it fit in a 9 x 13 pan.  In fact I added a few more tortillas and another cup of cheese (I used 4-cheese Mexican blend) so I could make a third layer.  It fit perfectly.  I think I will make it in two 9 x 9 pans next time and freeze one for later. Sour cream on top was really good.  This is a very filling dinner.

This was "great".  I made it last night and have about half left over which will probably be even better for leftovers! I halved the ground beef and used only one can of beans and used a 9x13 pan.  I also used corn tortillas which probably held it together better. Thanks for a great recipe.  Oh yes, one of the best parts is that clean up is easy and once you have it in the oven, that's it!

This recipe was enjoyed by my family. I halved everything except the cheese. I baked it in a 3 quart Corning Ware casserole, which was perfect!! Like many others, we thought the recipe a bit bland. I did add 1/2 teaspoon of cumin, but next time will add even more. Like many others, I used salsa instead of taco sauce, since that is what I had on hand. I also used crushed tomatoes instead of diced tomatoes. Next time I would add extra crushed tomatoes to make the recipe a little more moist. Overall, a great recipe!!!

Review:
Rating:

dateLastModified:

userID:
9003244
Display Name:
LuckyMay
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1

4
favoritesCount:
64
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/944022.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe for the first time yesterday for friends, and it was a huge hit! Everyone loved it, and there were hardly any leftovers. What I read from quite a few other reviews was that the mixture was too wet, which made the tortillas mushy. So I only used about half of the 16oz jar of taco sauce, and did not mix the refried beans into the meat. I let the meat mixture with everything else cook for about 30 minutes, which helped the mixture to absorb much of the liquid. After spreading a thin layer of the meat mixture in the pan (a 9x13 pan worked great), I dolloped the 1 can of refried beans on top of the meat and cheese before placing the first layer of tortillas in the pan. Then repeated with the second layer. I ended up only using 1 can of refried beans, and it was enough. I also placed the tortillas in a dry saute pan one at a time to dry them out a bit before placing in between the layers of the meat, cheese, and beans. After baking the dish for about 30 minutes, I drizzled the remaining taco sauce on top and added some sliced scallions. Served with fresh guacamole, sour cream, and salsa. Fantastic!

country:

text:
This is a solid recipe. There are just two of us, so I split it into two separate pie tins and popped one in the freezer for an easy meal later on.  The tortillas I bought fit just about right in the pie pans. Followed other cooks' advice and smeared the beans on a double layer of tortillas. Worked out great! Can't attest to the frozen pie yet, but the fresh one was on point. I pretty much used what I had on hand - just 1# beef, half an onion, some taco seasoning, picante instead of taco sauce, cheddar and jack instead of Colby, whole wheat tortillas - the recipe is pretty forgiving that way. I think corn or additional beans would also be nice in the sauce layers, or some condensed cheddar cheese soup.  I served it in wedge shaped slices with a dollop of sour cream, picante sauce, a couple of olives, and some sliced avocado. My honey gave it a "D" and then clarified that the D stood for "Delicious ". :)

text:
i essentially turned this into mexican lasagna. made some small changes....

1. I used 1/2 chorizo and half beef with taco seasoning.
2. i used the tomato and chile w/cilantro and lime juice (all in 1 can)and mixed that in with the refried beans.

here is how i did the layers.

taco sauce, tortilla, bean/tomato, meat, cheese and then repeat.  after the last topping of cheese i ran some taco sauce in rows over the top and sprinkled with some olives...very very good.

you can add some fritos for crunch and sour cream for creaminess when served.

text:
This recipe is very kid friendly,  kids can help assemble their own individual pie with the toppings they like.  I used whole wheat tortillas and only used three for each pie.  I made two small pies, and three larger ones using this recipe.  One small pie was for a vegetarian, so just used sauce and a variety of beans (whole and veg refried) , tomatoes, onions and cheese.  Made one kicking up the heat for my son and minus cheese and my husbands without beans ( allergic to them) and my daughters minus tomatoes and extra beans.  Everyone enjoyed their pies!  Much quicker to make than enchilladas and just as yummy!  Thanks for sharing this recipe.

text:
Really good recipe. I made the following (minor) modifications: I have a 4-year-old son and a boyfriend who eats a lot, so I definitely didn't cut the recipe as some suggested; the leftovers got eaten. I omitted the green chilis and used regular diced tomatos rather than the ones with chile peppers. I also used mild taco sauce and I'm sure if you prefer spicy then medium would be good. I also took the advice of another reviewer and used 2 tortillas per layer. This recipe is a keeper.

Lovely!  Made this for my hubby and 2 young kids... although cut down on the amounts and the spice!  Used one pd beef, half an onion, 2 cloves minced garlic, half can olives, no chili peppers, regular diced tomatoes with celery and onion, mild taco sauce, 1 can refried beans and 3 large tortillas cut up to fit a round glass casserole (it's all I had on hand). Let me start by prefacing with "I am not a casserole dish/dinner type of person." But this one is a keeper recipe. Next time I'm making a full batch to save one for the freezer!

Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2012-01-02T17:10:51.673
helpfulCount:
2
userID:
4569223
Display Name:
Spatia1Anoma1y
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
4
favoritesCount:
39
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/350826.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I don't like to review recipes that I didn't follow exactly but this was such a good base recipe that I have to give it 5 stars! I made changes to suit my own taste. For the meat sauce I followed the recipe except made the following changes: 1 lb ground beef, 6 oz can black olives, 16 oz can black beans- drained and rinsed, 1 large chopped jalapeno with seeds, 1 chopped green pepper, 1 package taco seasoning, 3/4 of the jar of taco sauce, and about 1 cup of salsa I threw in just to use it up. I also seasoned the meat right away with salt and pepper. I mixed a 16 oz can of refried black beans with about a 1/2 cup of sour cream in a separate bowl then layered it on the tortillas followed by the meat sauce then cheese. I used pepperjack instead of Colby except on the top. I'd give it a spice rating of 3 on a scale of 1(mild) to 5 (hot). I used two tortillas between each layer but next time will use three. I also only made three layers to try to cut down on carbs but the bottom half turned out soggy so next time I will use a shallower pan, more tortilla layers with less filling in between, and nix the bean/sour cream mix for another can of whole beans in the meat. The mistakes were my own and the flavor still excellent! I made 6 small burritos with the leftover meat sauce, tortillas, and extra cheese I had, wrapped well and froze for later. Again, 5 stars for a great base recipe!

text:
We loved this! I used all the ingredients plus a can of black beans and half a bag of frozen yellow corn. We used a 9x13 baking dish. Per others' suggestions we put the refried beans on the tortillas first. The way we layered the tortillas was we put one on each end of the pan so that they over lapped in the middle and then cut one in half and put a half on each end so the tortilla layer was close to the same thickness the length of the pan.

text:
I just served this for dinner and it was a big hit.  I used ground turkey instead of beef and replaced the green chilis with chipote peppers in adobo sauce to compensate for the lighter flavor of the meat and it was great! The chiopoltes needed to be choppped up, but it was well worth the extra step. I also mashed a can of black beans and added them to the refried beans, smearing them on the tortillas as others suggested, but wonder if it would have held together better with the beans in the mix.  I used 1/2 the recipe for homemade taco seasoning found on ths site because I didn't have a packaged version on hand.  Next time I may just make the filling and use that in burritos.

text:
Everybody loved this. I halved the recipe and it fit perfectly into a round 2 qt glass casserole dish.  I didn't have the small can of green chiles, so I just omitted them.  I also didn't have the taco sauce, so I substituted medium salsa.  Worked great.  I followed another reviewer's suggestion to spread the beans on the tortilla and then layer "beany side down" as opposed to mixing the beans in.  It worked very well.  I also used more cheese than called for because we love cheese :)  I did want to say, that per other reviewers, I used three tortillas per layer. It was a little too thick for my preference.  Next time I will only use two tortillas per layer and it should be perfect.  All in all a GREAT recipe that I will DEFINITELY make again :)

text:
I made the 8 serving version and it was excellent!  I added a packet of taco seasoning (no water) and it really added an enhanced flavor.  I used mild taco sauce and this dish was not too hot at all.  I used Mexican cheese.  I did the refried beans separate, but next time I'll just mix it in with the meat for ease of spreading.  I put this in a 2 quart casserole using only 4 tortillas (I had no problems with sogginess).  I layered it 1/3 meat & beans then 2 tortillas....1/3 meat & beans with 1/2 cheese then 2 tortillas....topped with 1/3 meat & beans and remaining cheese.

text:
Very good.  I didn't read the reviews before-hand and did not make any of the changes suggested.  I think doubling up the tortillas would just make it too "bready" instead of allowing for the flavor of the meat/bean mixture.  And I did mix everything together as instructed.  I do not like spreading layers like this and always think it's a hassle, so I wouldn't want to spread twice.  (I'm not sure I find the point in separating the beans.)  I scaled this down to only 1/4 the recipe and it was plenty for me for a couple of days, including taking it for lunch.  (It heats up in a microwave reasonably well.)  Not sure how you'd fit the entire recipe in any casserole.

text:
This has got to be one of the best dishes my husband has ever made me.  We did modify the ingredients slightly to make it VERY spicy because we love it that way (almost burn your mouth!).  I bought hot taco sauce, habanero/jalapeno refried beans, habanero spicy shredded cheese, super hot salsa, chipotle hot sauce, added 1 habanero pepper, and can of diced tomatoes with habaneros (seeing the hot theme here).  Basically anything I can substitute a spicier version of the item I did.  FYI - if you have a Mexican section in your grocery store, that's where you will find these items and they typically are cheaper.  We let the mixture simmer longer (40 minutes).  This could easily be made in the crockpot to slow cook the mixture then follow the directions to layer/bake afterwards. I can only imagine how delicious that would taste with all those spices simmer all day long.  I will try and let you know!

Display Name:
Mandy Mealer

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I gave this 5 stars simply because my entire family of 6 (age 11 months to 36 yrs) loved it and cleaned their plates.  The picky 10 yr old asked for seconds!  GASP!    I didn't add the olives but only because I don't like them.  I used spicy refried beans and didn't add them to the meat but instead did as others suggested and smeared it onto the tortilla as I layered them.  I used probably WAY more cheese than it called for.  4 cups of colby shredded and 2 cups of mexican shreaded.  We like cheese!  I browned meat and added 2 packs of taco season (one mild and one cheesy), drained, added tomato, green chili, and taco sauce (mild) and simmered for 15 mins.  Layered into dish, then layer of tortilla bean side down, and then smothered with shreaded cheese and repeated.  When serving while still hot I added a little more cheese for the kids.  I served with shredded lettuce, chunky tomato with habeneros for the husband and corn for the kiddos.

I hate when people change the whole recipe... but I took others' advice and double-layered tortillas, used salsa instead of taco sauce and used taco seasoning to brown meat.  Husband and kids loved it!  It made a lot but leftovers heated well in microwave.  Could cut in 1/2 and just use 8x8 pan perfectly.  Also, kids don't like spicey and I accidentally used hot salsa and refried beans with jalapenos but I made the whole dish the night before for ease of use and it was not too hot and reheated well (not mushy) so a timesaver for me.  Definitely in the rotation!

We enjoyed.  I used my cast iron skillet to layer the burrito pie and bake. I also made the re-fried beans using a can of pintos.  Heat small amt. of oil in skillet, add cumin and cayenne to taste, when hot, add can of beans with all liquids.  Mash with ricer and cook to proper consistancy.  Better and healthier than canned refried beans.  Also, I will try green salsa in place of taco sauce next time.

text:
I changed a couple things around but followed the basic rules of the recipe which I'm sure would be great without my changes.  I used 1lb of ground turkey in addition to the lb of ground beef, a verde taco sauce.  I like to sauté my onions until they are almost translucent and then add the meat.  Then I didn't add the cheese until the end and I put it on top.  Next time I will add more green chili's I really like the flavor.  Also spray the bottom of your pan place tortilla then put refried bean (98% fat free) then meat mixture and continued to top where I placed the cheese.  I was able to save calories and it was still just as delicious.

This turned out great! I made a few changes along the way. I halved the beef (used veggie beef crumbles),used 1 small onion, used about 1 tbsp of taco seasoning on the beef,  used half a bottle of taco sauce, used more than half of the lg. bottle of chunky salsa,used a ton more cheese (mexican and chihuahua cheese), used the whole can of mild chiles and less than half a can of the tomatoes. country:

text:
This was way salty, but it is not the recipes fault...I made the recipe as stated, but followed the advice of other reviewers who reccommended the taco seasoning. Do not use taco seasoning...it is far too salty. There is several recipes on here that tell you how to mix your own spices for taco seasoning, and it allows you to have control over the season that you are adding. I would ammend the recipe as follows:

I believe this is best made in 2 deep pie pans as other reviewers have stated.

Double the tortilla's, it will hold up better.

Do not mix the ingrediants all into one big glob, spread the beans on the tortilla's as others have reccommended.

Spray pie pans, and use the tortilla as the bottom layer, it get's nice and crispy. 

Skip the taco sauce...slimeville. Serve it on the side. 

Cook the ground beef, onion, chili's and all the other spices to allow for flavor melding.

text:
Wow!  I took the advice of others and added a few tweaks of my own and they definitely made this a 5 star recipe!  Here is what I did:
I doubled up the tortillas so the pie wouldn't get soggy.  I didn't add the beans to the meat mixture but put a layer of beans in between the tortillas. I added 2 T. taco seasoning to the meat mixture and let it simmer 30 minutes. Definitely need more cheese with this recipe (I used double.) I baked it for 3o minutes and broiled it on low at the end to make it brown on top. With these changes it is fabulous!!

Very easy and oh so good.  I make this all the time for my husband, and have passed the recipe on to many friends.  It's so easy to make and reheat.  Don't let the chile peppers scare you- it's not hot.  The flavors blend perfectly.  Will make again and again.  Thanks for the recipe.

userID:

Display Name:
tamarak86

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yummy!! It's just me and my husband, so I halved the recipe. We still had enough for 2 nights. I used an 8x8 dish. I chopped 1/2 of a large yellow onion. Sauted it in butter. Added minced garlic. Added 1 lb ground beef.Add 1/2 pack of taco seasoning. When the meat was cooked I added 3/4 can of black olives(sliced),a whole 4oz can diced green chilies, 1/2 of an 8oz bottle of hot taco sauce(hubby doesn't do spicy)I then gave it 2 big squirts of the mild green taco sauce, 1/2 can of tomato sauce(I don't do diced tomatoes)and let simmer for 10 to 15 min. I heated up a can of refried beans. I then began layering. I sprayed the dish and put down 2 tortillas, then beef mixture, then grated cheddar (it's what I had)then following other suggestions I smeared the refried beans on a tortilla and place it bean side down added another tortilla and repeated the layer again. Then I added the last of the meat mixture and more cheese and the rest of the olives. I used approx. 12oz grated cheese and 6 tortillas total. I then baked for about 30 min at 350. This was the perfect amount for me and my hubby for dinner and leftovers.

text:
*A regularly rotated dish!  I've found that it's better if you do use 2 lbs of ground beef, one pkg of Taco Seasoning (I use Lawry's), TWO 7 oz cans of Embasa's Salsa Mexicana (instead of taco sauce), a 14 oz can of diced tomatoes with chiles, extra onion, less than 2 oz of black olives, and I chop up a few jalapeno's for some heat.  We don't like beans, so we don't add them. And, GOBS of cheese - generally, we use the Mexican Four Cheese blend.  Also, I rip up the tortillas to fit into the 9X13 pan.  AWESOME!  Everyone who I've made it for LOVES it.

text:
My husband and I loved this recipe.  It is really flavorful.  I followed the recommendations of the others and didn't mix the beans with the meat.  I cooked the meat with seasoning 5 min, added the garlic and onion and cooked for another 5 min, added can of tomatoes, green chiles, and taco sauce.  In my opinion, you shouldn't drain the tomatoes b/c there isn't enough liquid to simmer.  Then I layered meat, cheese, bean covered tortilla (bean side down) like the others.  IMPORTANT: I think the amounts have been changed from the original recipe b/c there is NO WAY this is as big as others have rated it.  I layered all the meat, etc. with 6 tortillas and it all fit into a 2 1/2 quart deep baking dish (corningware).  Just thought I'd let everyone know that before you cut it in half and don't have enough to feed everyone!

text:
Made this tonight and let me quote what my hubby said..."I'm lovin this"  The only changes I made were omitted the olives (dont like them), used taco seasoning instead of salsa, and did not mix the refried beans w/ the meat, I layered separately.  I couldn't decide if I wanted to use flour tortillas or corn tortillas, hubby a fan of corn and flour for me, so I used a huge casserole dish and on one half I used flour and the other half I used corn.  I sprinkled cheddar cheese all over the whole thing and baked.  Yummy!  I did pre fry both kinds of tortillas prior to layering them.  Will most definately make again.

text:
My family really enjoyed this, they all had 2 helpings. I thought it would be a bit spicier with the Rotel tomato/peppers, green chili's and the Pace "medium" taco sauce, but it wasn't at all. My guys topped theirs with sour cream, but said it was great either way. It made a huge pan, would feed a lot of people. It was simple to make. I didn't care for it much, it was okay as far as my tastes...maybe I expected too much with all the reviews and high star rating. I would give it a 3 because it wasn't bad, it really was okay, but my gang liked it well enough for 4.5 stars. I did double the cheese as one 8 oz. package only covered the first couple of layers. It didn't say exactly if the flour tortillas overlapped, or if you had to cut them to fit the gaps, I overlapped mine and used 18 (3 layers of 6). It was worth preparing and my gang wants it again sometime. I, however, was not impressed.

text:
A huge hit!  There is a reason why so many have given this 5 stars.  My family couldn't get enough of it (including my two-year-old).  I also followed the advice of others and tweaked it a little. 1) I used taco seasoning with the ground beef 2) I left out the black olives 3) I used so much more cheese - 2 full packages of shredded cheese 4) I didn't use a can of green chiles and instead used 2 cans of Rotel 5) I doubled the tortillas and put the refried beans on the tortillas 6) I served it on lettuce with sour cream and our favorite salsa on the side.  I don't understand any of the bad reviews of it tasting bland or being horribly mushy looking.  It was packed full of flavor and looked really good.  As my husband said at the end of dinner, "this recipe is definitely a keeper."

My family raved about this! I've been requested to make this instead of "regular" tacos from now on! I did make two changes... first, I used two cans of black beans instead of refried beans because I didn't think the look of refried beans mixed with the meat would be appetizing. Second, I only used 8 oz. of taco sauce but only because I didn't read the recipe thoroughly enough and it was all I had in the house. It came out perfect so I don't know if I would use 16 oz next time... might make it too soupy..?  Anyway, I give it 5 stars and I will definitely be making it again!

text:
I am rating this with 5 stars cuz my husband & my son said I had to. I ended up using too large of a baking dish so I didn't have enough layers and I forgot to add the taco sauce. Even with that this still turned out excellent. I added some cumin to the meat & we added our own taco sauce at the end. I halved the recipe and then my husband seemed to be upset when he saw that there was only a little left over. As far as someone saying the tortillas are soggy, well that's true. Every casserole type recipe I have ever made with tortillas in them have always comme out soggy. I like them soggy. My 8 yr old said that the meat filling would be great in tortilla fried like a chimichanga. We will definatly keep this recipe and make it again.

userID:
483954
Display Name:
ECS
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
49
favoritesCount:
57
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a pretty good recipe with some modifications and a combination of other users’ suggestions.  It’s like Mexican lasagna.  Halve the recipe for a standard 9X11 pan. I used salsa for texture, not taco sauce. I used one regular sized can refried beans and one black beans - again for texture or it’s a mushy mess. I used regular tortillas but overlapped a lot (if not - it’s a mushy mess). I did not mix in the beans with the meat, but I instead spread the beans on the tortillas, laid them face down on the pan, and then added the meat on top. Nothing fancy or amazing about this one. A quick and easy dish for a group.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2004-08-09T16:14:01.92

My husband and guests LOVED this recipe and it was pretty simple to make too :) I did subsitute some of the items for things I thought would make it a bit better tasting. I'm from the South where we like it zesty & spicy :) I took out the olives, used Taco seasoning instead of taco sauce, used one can regular refried beans and another of Chipotle refriend beans (spicy beans), and fresh homemade tortillas. It turned out awesome. When I was making it my husband was kind of judgemental, but he was apologizing afterwards! Enjoy!!

text:
Quick and easy! I only used 1 can of refried beans and 1 pound of beef. I used shredded cheddar instead of colby. I placed in a 9x13 and only had 2 layers of tortilla's. I used tomatoes without the chile's. I was so afraid that this would be spicy but it wasn't at all and I could have gone full strength. This turned out great! I placed foil over top the last 10 minutes in the oven to keep the cheese from hardening. This is a fabulous dish that isn't fancy but is very great family fare.

text:
Just got the Allrecipes Cookbook w/this recipe in it.  WONDERFUL!!!  Very easy to make because with a conventional lasagna you have to boil the noodles instead you use tortillas.  I want to try using tortillas in making a conventional lasagna too. I ommitted the chillies, olives, and tomatoes w/chillies and just used 14.5oz. of stewed tomatoes w/garlic.  That's what I had in the house.  It turned out great.  My family doesn't care for spicy/hot food so ommitting the chillies didn't make a difference in the taste to us.  If you like mexican, you'll love this guaranteed!!
