This recipe was good but I knew it wouldn't be spicy since green chilies were the only thing that resembled anything spicy and they don't have a lot of flavor.  I made the meat sauce per directions and then tasted.  I added about a TBS more minced garlic, garlic powder, onion powder and chipotle pepper powder.  It was then acceptable to all tastes -- those that liked spicy foods and those that didn't.  Without the add-ins the sauce was VERY bland.

My only problem with this recipe is that, after reading the other reviews, I decided I would probably add some taco seasoning.  So when the recipe was as it was, it really lacked something, and, as I added the taco seasoning bit by bit, it started to bite back a little (a good thing), but it still needed something.  The way it worked out, it ended up being a little too spicy for my taste, but I liked it and my family loved it.

text:
This is a new family favorite!  I've made it several times now and its very easy to make and doesn't take a very long time.

We found it easier to use the large flour tortillas 4 1/2 of them.  If you tear some in half, you can use one, and then one half to make a perfect layer.

I serve it with a salad for a complete meal.  Oh, and I find it makes about 12 servings, not 16.

For those of you on weight watchers, at 12 servings, it's 11 points per serving.

text:
This is a very versatile recipe. I decided to make my pie in two separate cake pans to suit my families different tastes. I made one with seasoned black beans and one with seasoned pinto beans. They were both a hit. I made my own taco seasoning and used salsa instead of taco sauce. I didn't want this to turn out soggy so I drained the beans and the tomatoes. I doubled the tortillas for each layer, as suggested by other reviewers. I did not have any issues at all with this turning out soggy or the tortillas dissolving.  Fantastic and easy way to have delicious burritos!

Rating:

dateLastModified:

helpfulCount:

userID:
6559456
Display Name:
Emeril LaWannabe
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

0
madeRecipesCount:
5
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674168.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Awesome!  Just Awesome.  However, a few tweaks just like everyone else.  I don't like the fat content in refried beans so I used two cans of rinsed pinto beans dropped in the food processor with a little oil, some Garlic Pepper seasoning and a couple spoonfuls of the Tomatoes with Chilis.  I used taco sized corn tortillas just because I like the way they bake into dishes like this. I also agree with one of the other reviewers that more cheese is better.  I used a 24 oz. mix of 4 Cheese Mexican and Taco blend. Hey, we're from Wisconsin.  Start with the largest fry pan you have and it will still be full once everything is in it. I didn't have green chilis so I used a few pickled jalapenos finely diced.  Simmer the meat-bean-olive-tomato mix for at least 20 mins, and PLEASE, taste it before you assemble it.   Make sure the flavor is right before you build this. I used a 9x15 foil pan and it made three layers with 6 corn tortillas overlapped on each layer.    Tent it with foil for the first 30 min then remove it and let the top cheese get a bit brown.  Did I say Awesome?  This is a keeper and a great take and bake meal.

COOKINCHRISSY

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I made exactly as written, except for reducing the amount of meat to just one pound (per the advice of another cook) and used a 12 oz bottle of taco sauce instead of 16. Had I used 2 lbs of meat, then it would have been WAY too much! I kept the amount of all the other ingredients the same. My family likes things a bit spicy, so I used hot green chili peppers, refried beans with jalapeno, and a medium spicy taco sauce. However, you'll definitely need to up the amount of cheese. I used two 2-cup bags, which worked out just fine. Family would like to eat it again!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
when my teenage daughter started bringing her friends over after football games and they brought their football player boyfriends, I had to figure out how to feed a lot of hungry people on the cheap and this recipe is definitely one of the favorites. I took it to a family gathering and they all loved it too so it is now something we all have on our regular meal rotations. as far as the soggy tortilla thing goes, I have found if you use cheapo tortillas and double it up rather than one of the thick and fluffy mission ones, you won't get the mush in the middle. I also season my meat with a package of taco seasoning and that adds a ton of flavor.
Review:

text:
A good hearty meal that will feed a whole army! I halved the recipe and still had lots of leftovers. I didn't any chili's because I don't like the heat,  and used powered taco seasoning instead of liquid since I had it on hand.  I also didn't add the refried  beans to the beef-tomato mixture because it seemed so thick already,  instead I spread them on the tortillas like another reviewer suggested. I also put a layer of guacamole and sour cream over the top. It was a hit!  Will definitely be making again.

text:
BIG WINNER! The kids & the husband loved this dish. I made this once so far & I used some of the suggestions right off the bat...I used 2 tortillas (not 1) for each layer & spread the refried beans on top of the tortilla (instead of adding to the beef mixture) before starting the next next layer to avoid sogginess. I made 2 pie plates but definitely ran short on the meat mixture for the 2nd plate. Next time I would go a little lighter with the meat while layering to avoid falling short again. Will certainly add this to my recycled recipe list for sure! It's awesome the next day too...not soggy!

text:
This was pretty good. I tweaked the process a bit however. I have trouble swallowing so when meat is overcooked I pretty much can't eat it. It's alot easier to overcook meat than ppl would think. With the directions you're cooking the ground beef to death. Cook the onions and garlic when you start cooking the ground beef and when they're is just a tiny amount of pink in the meat add the mixture then simmer. I only  did it until it looked like it was about to boil, then a little over 5 mins after that. It continues to cook taken off the burner and in the oven. It came out really good. I'll prolly still fool around with the time on the meat, but that's the only thing. Other than that I changed nothing.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good flexible recipe. I halved the recipe. Left out olives (2 don't like them). Had some cooked ground beef, but not that much, added onion, pepper, fresh tomato and corn for bulk along with some taco seasoning. Didn't have a lot of shredded cheese so did part American cheese. Once I had it assembled looked dry (no canned tomatoes or taco sauce). Put a small can of tomato sauce, a big spoon of red salsa and two big spoons of green salsa (from the fridge) and a tsp of chili powder in the blender to make my own sauce. Poured that over the top and then added the final layer of cheese. A little salty (American cheese?) but still very tasty.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/341953.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Omg this pie is soooooo good! I halved the recipe and used leftover chicken from the Easy Cheesy Chicken recipe on allrecipes instead of ground beef. I heated up the chicken in the skillet, then added an onion and one clove garlic, and then mixed in 3/4 can black olives, 1/2 can green chiles, whole can rotel, and 3oz taco sauce. I used a 2.5 qt casserole dish and layered my casserole as follows: chicken mixture, shredded Mexican cheese, tortillas (with refrained beans spread on) bean side down. I repeated that twice. On top I had a layer of chicken mixture, refried beans, 1/4 can black olives, and cheese. Baked it for about 27 minutes and it was amazing. Will definitely be making this again but next time will try ground beef. Next time I will also have to make 2 separate pies bc my picky husband doesn't like any of the veggie ingredients. I'm sure I used more cheese than called since I just sprinkled it over each layer. Great recipe!! Thanks for posting!!

None
text:
I observed many comments, so i decided to deep fry the flour tortillas in peanut oil.  The middle one may be a little soggy, but not gooey.  I used a Pie Tin and put a tortilla on the bottom, (this is better for serving), then add some mixture, cheese, then repeat again. I add another tortilla on the top, adding shredded cheese and chopped green onion to the top after 20 minutes. and let cook another 10.  A lot of variations for this recipe, I love it.  This batch mix was shredded Chicken, Pablano Pepper, Red Onion and crushed Black Olives and refried beans.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
We're from SE Texas so TexMex is the way of life,LOL! I prepare Mexican dishes often and am always looking for more to try. This dish is good. I added a little corn. Add taco seasoning and/or cumin and chili powder to make it taste truly authentic. I sub'd salsa for taco sauce cause I didn't have any. I followed someones recommendation to use 2-3 tortillas for the tortilla layers instead of a single layer. A salad on the side and some sour cream on top and it's good. I often put avocado or guacamole with these dishes if I have it. The cumin and chili powder make it taste like Mexican food should in Texas. It makes a ton so half it or freeze it unless you need that much. I had to use a lasagna pan! We have big eaters, and this type of dish is almost better as leftovers!

country:
None
text:
This was really good and I will make again for sure. The filling is fantastic and would work for regular burritos as well. I cut the recipe in half and am glad I did. It was plenty for my family of 4 and we even have leftovers. I used 1 can of Kuners refried black beans with roasted chilies. I skipped the can of green chilies since my beans had them in it already. I also did not mix in the olives with the meat and beans. I layered them on top of the cheese layers. My tortillas did not get soggy at all, so maybe it is the brand of tortillas that some folks are using. I only used 1 pound of ground beef and 6 tortillas. This dish fit perfect in my Corningware 2.5 qt oval casserole dish. I served it with guacamole and sour cream.

None
text:
Looking for a new little 'something,' I was delighted when I saw this recipe.  I had all the ingredients on hand.  As someone suggested I simmered the ingredients 40-45 minutes to meld the flavors.  I had one and a half pounds of ground beef so added sausage that I had on hand.  I personally like the taste of the combination.  I had corn tortillas, that I prefer to flour, spread the beans on the tortillas again as suggested by another reviewer, and layered meat, cheese and tortillas - bean side down. Voilà - soggy tortilla problem solved.  Following the recipe with the recommended amount of beef (sausage) mix I had enough for 2 complete layers and finished with the last bit of meat mixture and topped with slices of sharp cheddar cheese. Halfway through baking added another can of sliced olives.  Again, taste being subjective I used half red and half green taco sauce as I love the green. You can top this recipe with any number of fun things - tomato, green onion, sour cream, etc., or eat just "as is." Delicious.  Thank you Kathie for sharing.

text:
DH and I really liked this one! I skipped the olives, used 9 LaTortilla Factory wheat tortillas for 3 layers.  I added salt & pepper and several dashes of hot sauce and used Mexican blend cheese. Baked for 40 minutes in a 13x9 pan. Great served with shredded lettuce, a dollop of Greek yogurt, and a few tortilla chips around the edge. It had a similar mouth-feel of a 7 layer dip! Cut the remainder into several squares, refrigerating overnight, then will put into a vacuum-seal bag and freeze for easy leftovers over the coming months.

text:
I know, I know, it's frustrating when recipes are reviewed after being significantly changed, but I made a VERY much scaled down version of this for my family of two tonight with great success, so I thought I'd share. I used the site's tool to change the servings to four and followed the proportions exactly EXCEPT for ommitting the can of chiles, adding a tablespoon of chopped jalapeño when cooking the diced onions, and using one full can of refried beans and one full can of tomatoes with chilies, just because I didn't want to have a half can of each leftover. I used an 8X8 dish sprayed with cooking spray, and I spread the first tortilla with the bean mixture, flopped it bean side down into the dish, then proceeded as per directions. I couldn't figure any other way to get the bean/meat mix evenly on the bottom without messing up the non-stick spray, and it worked. I let it rest for about ten minutes before slicing and serving, and topped it with a few chopped olives, a couple of dollops of sour cream, and some chopped cilantro. Delish, and I only have leftovers for one meal. Maybe when I'm entertaining, I'll make it as written, but with some tweaks, this worked for my small family.

text:
After reading some of the reviews I did make a couple of small changes.  We always substitute ground turkey for ground beef so I did add 1/3 of a pack of salt free taco seasoning to the meat mixture. As I was adding the rest of the ingredients I could smell the spiciness of the dish so I asked hubby to taste test the mix prior to adding the can of chilies. He thought it was spicy enough to I left them out but decided to add a cup of black beans and a cup of corn to help with the texture. I used the 97% fat free ground turkey with a 1/3 of a packet of salt free taco seasoning instead of ground beef, non fat refried beans, all salt free canned goods when possible and low fat cheese. I did also spread the refried beans like cake icing on the tortillas rather than add to the mix. This was awesome and will be added to my list of casseroles!

text:
We really liked this recipe for a quick week night dish. I used half turkey and half beef (hubby couldn't tell). I only had 8 oz of taco sauce so I used that and 8 oz of salsa; added extra olives because we love them. I followed others advice on doubling the the tortillas and spreading the beans onto the tortillas to make the job easier. I baked half of the recipe in a 9x9 dish and froze the other half in a 9x9 disposable foil pan covered with foil. A few weeks later, I removed the frozen one from the freezer and placed straight in a 325 degree oven for about 85 minutes (Uncovered the last 30 minutes); it was super and we did not find this soggy at all. Thanks for the recipe.

text:
I've made this twice now and thought it was pretty good. I am only giving it 4 stars because I had to make  many modifications for it to be delicious. I followed other reviewers' suggestions and added the beans to the tortillas. I used both refried black beans and refried pinto beans to mix it up. I also substituted white corn tortillas for the flour tortillas. This was a personal preference, and I don't think it makes or breaks this dish, but it was a nice variation. I also did not find it to be spicy as it says in the blurb, but that's fine with me, because I am not a fan of super spicy food. This dish is a good one. I love that it makes enough to freeze for later. There is plenty of room for variation, and I think it's yummy enough to serve to company. I will definitely keep this in my collection.

text:
I used 13oz of cheese and 8 lower carb tortillas (our brand tastes like normal); I made the meat layers a touch too thick so I wasn't able to use all 12, which meant the end result was kind of sloppy (but still tasty). I also added a finely minced jalapeño and used half a tablespoon of granulated garlic in place of 2 teaspoons fresh. I used a 9x13 pan and my biggest skillet without anything overflowing, so complaints regarding the recommended pan sizes are very subjective. I will make it again but I'll use all 12 tortillas and probably add another can of olives.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this last night and it was awesome! I am newly married and didn't pay enough attention to my mom's cooking lessons growing up, so I'm trying to start of easy. This recipe was definitely easy to follow and came out great. I followed the advice from some of the other reviews. I cooked the 2 lbs of meat with the chilis and tomatoes, 1/2 of an onion (my husband is not a big onion guy), 1/2 of a red bell peper, and 1/2 of a green bell pepper. I threw in one packet of taco seasoning (without water) and used half of the amount of taco sauce so it would have a better consistency. I layered everything in a 9 by 11 pan and amazinly it all fit. This is how I layerd it: meat mixter, cheese, tortilla with beans (bean side down).I also doubled the amount of tortillas in the layers. It ended up tasting like an unfried chimichanga! My husband and I love it!

text:
Excellent!  I took the suggestion from others and spread the refried beans on the tortillas rather than mix them in the meat.  My husband and I like it hot so I added 1 can of diced jalapenos to the beans.  Beans are easier to spread if you mix them in a bowl and put them in the microwave for a couple of minuets. They soften up.

text:
Changes made: mixed beans and olives seperate and made another layer with this mix. Added two packs of taco seasoning instead of garlic and onion into beef mix after browning. Used so much more cheese, in between layers - almost 4 cups. It was a very good tasting dish but better the next day type casserole. The reason is because it just falls apart when you cut into it hot. It was so overwhelming that the presentation turned the kids' noses upwards. After I stuck it in the fridge and cut a piece in the morning to take to lunch, it was manageable and square :) Will make again if I need to have something all ready to go and can heat up individual pieces.

Wow.  Yum, yum, yum.  My new favorite!!! I almost licked the plate!  Very easy, too.   I changed a few things... I used corn tortillas instead of flour just because I like them better (I think it makes it taste more authentic mexican) I left out the olives because my family doesn't like them.  I used Rotel with green chilies and instead of a can of refried beans, I used Frito Lay bean dip which has more flavor.  I also didn't have taco sauce so I just used salsa.   It was wonderful!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Absolutely stellar. This recipe is very adaptable to personal taste and whatever ingredients you have on hand.  I was slowing cooking a pork butt in some chicken stock (go figure, I know it sounds crazy but it's what I had on hand) to turn into pulled pork sandwiches. But when I found this recipe, I decided to use the shredded pork in place of the ground beef. I served the dish to my bible study group and everyone (super hungry men, women and kids!) raved over it. I served it with some brown rice also cooked with chicken broth as a side dish. People had the option to top the pie with sour cream and shredded lettuce, if they chose to. I plan on making this again tonight just for me and the kids.   Oh yeah, I used black beans instead of refried; omitted the chili peppers cuz i'm just a punk like that; and used whole wheat tortillas. I also mixed the taco sauce with some ricotta cheese and then began layering the meat, tortillas, beans, sauce mixture, and cheese as if making a lasagna.

text:
This is an excellent change from regular burritos, enchiladas, tacos, ect. I followed the advice from other reviewers and spread the refried beans on the tortillas individually, keeping the meat in separate layers and adding taco seasoning mix to the meat. Also used two tortilla thickness to eliminate soggy torts...it was really good and the leftovers hold up well (which is great because I take them to work for lunch). I used more cheese than the original recipe called for, but this recipe is really adaptable...you can eliminate certain ingredients and add what you like to customize it. Topped off with shredded lettuce, chopped cilantro, sour cream and slices of avocado made this a delicious dinner~thanks for the recipe!

text:
We love this spicy so this is what I do. I use a 9 X 13 pan. I use 2 pounds of hamburger meat, 1 can of refried beans (probably could use 2 but I liked the texture and taste with one can so I don't add the other can), I use 2 cans of rotel, half a jar of taco sauce and a lot more cheese! I add 2 packages of taco seasoning to meat and cook it with the onions and garlic, add in the other things listed above pluse the black olives. I use 3 tortillas stacked and break them to fill the shape of the rectangle pan. So simple, spicy and good.

text:
FANTASTIC! I was really doubtful about this recipe, but because of all the great reviews I tried it. Boy am I glad I did! I will be making this one often. The flavors all came together wonderfully. This is what I did different, only because I used the ingredients I had on hand. I omitted the black olives and in place of the canned tomatoes and taco sauce, I used a jar and a half of salsa. I also added taco seasoning to the beef. I only used 1 can of refried beans and chose to layer the beans rather than mix them in with the beef. My layers went like this, meat, tortilla, meat, cheese, tortilla, beans, meat, cheese, etc. ending with meat and cheese. I trimmed the tortillas to fit my casserole dish, not doubling them as some reviewers suggested and I added more cheese. Serving with sour cream gave it a finishing touch. This was very easy to essemble and quick to put together.

text:
Tried this today and it turned out delicious, as many have commented! Instead of using a jar taco sauce (I didn't have any) I just used canned tomatoes and used the taco seasoning recipe found in allrecipes as well. I added some mushrooms and used monterey instead of Colby. This recipe can easily be modified to suit your taste. I had some all-beef hotdogs as well, which I chopped into small pieces and added it into the ground beef. Everybody loved it! As other reviews have mentioned, two or three tortillas per layer did produce good results and also let the sauce/seasoning simmer with the ground beef for some time to enhance the taste as they blend together. Try it and you'll make it a staple! Good eating!

text:
Took this to a birthday party last night and I got rave reviews.  After reading other reviews, here are the changes I made.  I added a package of taco seasoning to the beef while cooking.  I also added some cumin.  I used salsa instead of taco sauce and used mexican cheese instead of colby cheese.  I used two tortillas together spreading the refried beans betweeen both tortillas.  Because of all the reviews I thought this dish would be a lot juicier that it was.  I do not think a double layer of tortillas was necessary because I thought it was a little to dry.  Will make again using only one layer of tortillas.

This was really good but it was hard to know how much meat mixture to put between each layer. Had I had a better idea of that I think it wouldve turned out much better. This was a hit at my house.  It wasn't too time consuming.  I added cumin and chili powder to the meat & onion mixture along with a little salt.  (I was afraid of it being too bland.)  I used a bottle of red enchilada sauce as I couldn't find taco sauce.  My family decided that next time we might try it in a 9x13 pan with corn tortillas. text:
to cut fat use ground turkey breast and low-fat everything else except tortillas, they get mushy. also, no taco sauce.  use plenty of southwest type seasoning (penzey's) and 7oz can of green chile for meat.  1 can of rotel for beans. 1 package of chez and only 6 tortillas.  so easy. bake and let sit for 15 or so minutes.  serve w/ lo-fat sour cream, shredded lettuce & salsa on the side. yumyum

text:
I made this last week with a few variations.  I did not have any taco sauce and my last onion went bad, so I simmered the beef in medium-hot salsa instead.  My husband dislikes refried beans, so I used canned chili w/beans and simmered together with the beef and salsa.  I also used corn tortillas rather than flour as I had just purchased some freshly made at our local store.  I layered meat/bean/salsa mixture, then cheese, then tortilla, and repeated.  Mine was a little hot for my kids, but they ate it up with white rice.  I will use mild salsa next time, and try the flour tortillas, and add some frozen corn in the mix.  Thanks for an excellent change to regular tacos and/or burritos.

city:

country:

text:
I made this exactly as written...but tried controlling fat and carbs... also, I divided the recipe in half... which was the only other "change" I made, seeing as there were many comments about the amount of "pie" that the recipe made.  I used 1# 93/7 beef, 1/2 onion, 1 tsp fresh garlic, 1/3 lg can black olives, 1/2 small can chilies, 1/2 can diced tomatoes w/ chilies, 8 oz mild taco sauce, 1 can vegetarian refried beans, 6 low carb tortillas and about 5 oz of an 8 oz block of 2% reduced fat sharp cheddar.  All this fit into an 11 X 7 pan and was enough for my husband and me and our 2 crabby kids who I knew wouldn't eat too much.  Honestly, it didn't look that great... and at first, it was just okay... but the flavor was really increased by adding some of the taco sauce right on top of the "pie."  I will be making this again... I do think I will use some more spice though... via tomatoes + jalapenos instead of "mild" rotel and medium taco sauce vs mild and maybe stick to full fat cheese, or maybe a mix of both.  It was easy, and really hit the spot for an inexpensive Mexican-inspired dish for a cold and lazy Friday night at home! Thanks!!

If your wanting to make this for a big get together (like superbowl etc...) then make the double batch.

This was an ok recipe, so I changed it a great deal. I prefer corn tortillas, so substituted those. I also did not add the olives, made my own enchilada sauce, added chipotle in adobe sauce to the beef mixture, and mashed black beans instead of using refried beans. Following advice from another poster, I used two stacks of tortillas for each layer.

To make sure it sticks together well, I added about 1.5 more cups of cheese. 

It came out nicely, but I'm glad I didn't make the recipe exactly as it is on the site.

text:
I just made this today and I have to say that I am really surprised at how good this is. I made this thinking that there is no way that this could be as good as everyone says it is. This is really, really good. I did layer the refried beans separately and I am glad that I did. The texture of the beans layered with the beef mixture is really good. I also used 2 tortillas per layer, no sogginess at all. This went together rather quickly, I did simmer the beef mixture for 30 min. and then baked for 30 min. I made 2 'pies', we had 1 for dinner and we have 1 leftover for lunch this week. Try this one, it is yummy!

text:
This recipe came out very yummy with a few modifications. I halved the recipe with the exception of the olives, green chiles, and rotel. However, it was so darn good, I'll likely make a full batch next time with the previously mentioned ingredients doubled. Since I read some reviews that this could be bland, I added a pack of taco seasoning and a minced jalapeno. This recipe is foolproof! Season it to your liking and you won't be disappointed. I followed the recommendation to spread the beans on the tortillas and in a 9 inch pie pan, I only used 3. Also, I made the meat mixture a day ahead of time and the taste went from a 2 star to 4 star! Terrific!

text:
Totally tasty stuff.  We all liked it.  I made exactly except for adding the packet of taco seasoning to the meat mix as suggested (is a great suggestion).  I added the beans (not quite all of the 2 cans) to the meat and it was fine.  I did let it simmer for about 30 min. before putting it all together. Just make sure you mix it up well, takes a minute to thoroughly distribute the beans. Mixture should be very thick. I put it in a large deep casserole dish and ended up with about 6 layers and I did double up on the tortillas in between layers.  Nothing soggy or mushy here at all.  Also needed extra cheese but this turned out great.  I used medium hot taco sauce and rotel tomatoes.  The spice level was just perfect for us.  Easy enough to spice it up if you like more heat.

text:
This was very tasty and easy! The recipe made way to much filling for 1 pie so I refrigerated it and made a second one later in the week. In order to make it look 'pretty' I used 3 tortillas per layer to give it distinction. I made the pie in a cake pan. The tortillas were slightly larger than the pan so I was able to put them in the pan and turn the excess up against the pan. I repeated this for each layer. This created a "crust".  Very nice looking and it kept its form nicely. I have had requests to make this again!

text:
I wish there were half stars because this one deserves 4 & a half!  I changed a few things mainly cutting back on the amount of ground beef to 1 lb which was plenty.  I omitted the green chile peppers and the dish wasn't lacking flavor at all because of it.  Although I think it's just a matter of preference I recommend using refried black beans.  I added in a couple palmfuls of chipotle seasoning which gave the dish a little heat.  

One thing I will do next time that was recommended in another review was to double/triple the tortillas when layering them so each layer or tortilla is a little more substantial.

text:
This was nice change to eating regular burritos. I did as others and left the hamburg and beans separate. I added taco seasoning to the burger along with the half onions, green chiles, tomatoes. I then spread fat-free refried beans on wheat tortillas, reduced fat cheese, blk olives and more onions (since we like crunchy onions). I used red sauce from can in lieu taco sauce, topped with cheese and garnished with more black olives. We put shredded lettuce and a dollop of light sour cream on top after baking. I did use an 11 X 15 baking dish, it was a lot but leftovers next day were great heated in microwave.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe. It's better called "Mexican Lasagna", since you're spreading a sauce made from burrito ingredients between layers of flour tortilla. The tortilla acts like lasagna noodles in a traditional Italian recipe. If you make this recipe, be aware that it is HUGE - it says it makes 16 portions. We made a half batch and basically it's at least three dinners for two. We used salsa instead of the taco sauce the recipe calls for, and we added some cumin and oregano to add a little extra flavor to the filling -- by itself, the filling was a little bland. I definitely think the filling portion of the recipe is open to substantial tweaking.

text:
Love this!  My mom requests this whenever I go home to visit and my guy friends love it!  Best of all, you can control how hot it is by using mild, medium, or hot taco sauce.  I use 3 tortillas for each layer.  It's never been runny, but I drain some of the liquid from the chiles and tomatoes.  Also, you might want to gradually add the taco sauce if you're worried about it being runny.  I serve this with lettuce, sour cream and cold beer.  Delicious!

Rating:

dateLastModified:
2007-03-18T12:46:26.613
helpfulCount:

userID:
988035
Display Name:
TALCOTT
isPro:
False
followersCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe last night and it was fantastic.  I will make again.  I change somewhat after reading reviews from others.  I sprayed my 13X9 pan with Pam and then spread a 6 oz. jar of medium taco sauce in bottom of pan in replace of the meat mixture.  This worked well.  I added only 1 6 oz. jar of medium taco sauce, 1/2 pack of taco seasoning, dried corinader, salt, valentine mexican sauce, 1/2 cup Pace Picante Sauce, meat, onions, garlic, 1 can of Rotel mexican style tomatoes, 4 oz or a little more of chopped hot jalapenos to the meat mixture and let simmer for 40 minutes.  I also warmed the tortillas before I started layering.  I cooked my beans separatedly with a little bit of butter and 1/2 cup of Pace Picante Sauce.  Then I layered as follows:  Spray Pam on bottom and sides, spread 1 6 oz. jar of taco sauce. Layer with warm tortillas, I also cut to make more of pie effect and made sure that it was covered as such.  Layered the beans on first layer, top with cheese and sprinkled hot jalepenos on top.  Then another layer of warm tortillas, toped with all of the meat mixture, then cheese, baked in oven 350 degrees for 25 to 30 minutes.  Let sit for 10 minutes after taking out of oven.  Serve with sour cream and salsa if you wish.  Had a really good taste.

text:
A great mexican night variation. I used 1.5 lbs ground beef mixed with 10oz bot. of taco sause, 1/2 c chunckey salsa, 6oz green chili sause, taco season packet,  1 can of refried beans 12 tortillas. Baked tortilla's on stone 5 min at 375. Used a 13X9 pan and followed the recipes layering instructions,used 4 tortillas per layer with 3 layers.  Used mozerrella and cheddar cheese.  Baked at 350 for 25 min. Looked and tasted great and stayed together and served well.  Definately will make again. Topped with lett/tom and sour cr. Super leftovers. Thank you for this great concept!

text:
Very Good!!  Everyone here enjoyed this dish, I only made a few changes. First, I omitted the olives and green chili's, since I have two small children.  The meat, rotel, taco seasoning and taco sauce was just fine for us.  Second, I did double up the tortilla's, I actually ended up using 16 in all for two layers and I spread the beans directly onto the tortilla.  The girls had sour cream with theirs and we had some homemade Salsa Verde with ours since we like it hot!  Homemade Mexican rice went perfect with.  This makes a ton so plan on sharing or freezing! By the way....I didn't tell my dh what this was called, he said "man this is good, tastes just like a burrito"  He had 3 servings!

helpfulCount:

userID:
1361225
Display Name:
starstar73
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
19

0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/154.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe, with the modifications suggested by other reviewers-- I cut the ingredients in half and assemble the casserole in a tall round dish, and it fits perfectly.  But because it's higher & denser, it needs to be baked for maybe 15-20 min. longer than the recipe says.  I add a package of (low sodium) taco seasoning to the browned beef, and nstead of taco sauce and tomatoes (and sometimes chiles), I just use a 16-oz jar of salsa.  I use a different one every time, but the ones I will use again are Newman's Own Chunky Salsa (Medium, with the small can of chiles) and La Victoria Suprema (Mild, doesn't need the extra chiles).  I add a big can of sliced olives instead of a small one, and a whole bag of frozen petite white corn kernels.  I use low carb/high fiber tortillas because they're hefty and so don't lose their integrity in the mix.  I probably use 2x the cheese as in the recipe, usually the pre-shredded Mexican-mix kind.  I serve it with corn chips, fresh diced avocado, and sour cream.  I always look at it and think "Wow, that's so much food" but every time, there are hardly any leftovers-- and this is really good reheated.  Highly recommended!
Review:

5

text:
I scaled this recipe for 12 people and served it this Memorial Day to 6 people, and there were NO leftovers.  I served with homemade spanish rice, tortilla chips and homemade pico de gallo.  This was one of the most delicious and flavorful dishes I have ever made.  I bought all mild ingredients and added my 1 spoonful of my pico de gallo and own dried spices before simmering (cumin, cilantro, cayenne pepper, salt and pepper). I also used 1/2 colby cheese and 1/2 american/pepper jack mix (I ran out of colby) and cut the tortillas into strips before overlapping in the dish.  I also used a 9 x 13 dish as suggested in reviews for 12 servings.  One of my guests had 4 servings!  Thank you so much... I will be making this again.

text:
I thought this was great, and reheated really well. I ended up using about three quarters of the meat mixture layered between 6 tortillas in a 2 1/2 quart dish, then rolled the rest of the mixture with some extra cheese in four leftover tortillas and popped them in the freezer -- 2 minutes on high in the microwave, and you've got a quick homemade burrito for lunch!

text:
I'd give this 4 to 4 1/2 stars because as the recipe stands, it's good. But, I had to spice it up a bit. If you like your mexican hot, this isn't going to cut it for you. I added hot sauce, red pepper flakes and cumin to the meet mix. I also only used 8 oz of hot taco sauce and it wasn't runny at all when we reheated it for left overs. But, it was excellent. We at it for a Sunday dinner and then had left overs on Monday. This was last week and my husband is already asking for me to make it again. Good base recipe!

userID:
1548553
Display Name:
Gigi
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

0
madeRecipesCount:
8
favoritesCount:
703
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674168.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Read most of reviews and I did not end up with a mushy mess with the following changes. I made the recipe for 8 people; 7 1/2" x 11 1/2" dish.
Added to 1# gr. beef-- 2 tsp. cumin & chili powder, salt & pepper to taste, 4 lg. minced cloves garlic plus the onion called for. Did NOT use the tomatoes and used only 1/2 can refired beans and a 1/2 jar of salsa. If you like hot food as
we do I added some jalepeno peppers. I
cut in half, six 8" whole wheat tortillas, laying the halves length-wise (overlapped a little) in the dish. I laid the first & third layer with straight edge of tortilla against the sides. The second layer I put the straight edge of the tortilla toward the middle. This way you have a tortilla with each bite!!! I used at least  1/2 pound of grated cheddar and topped the last layer with torilla chip crumbs easily found in the bottom of the bag!!! 
Made this 24 hours ahead so had to bake for about 45 minutes. It was not soggy or mushy. Served it on bed of shredded lettuce topped with sour cream, homemade salsa and guacamole. YUMMM!

text:
I made the half recipe and it filled an 8.5 x 12 inch baking dish perfectly. The recipe is just about perfect as is, but seasoning the ground beef/onion/garlic mixture with salt and pepper while browning is mandatory. Also, I strongly suggest topping the entire casserole with a medium to hot enchilada sauce a couple minutes before it comes out of the oven...it's the perfect way to finish this off (we use Margarita's brand hot salsa from Kansas City).

text:
My 5 yr old had seconds.  My husband REALLY LOVED it! Normally, when I make something new, he says it is okay.  However, he raved about how good the burrito pie is.  I used enchilada sauce instead of the taco sauce.  I did not put olives.  I was only able to fit about 5 tortillas into the casserole pan.  There was a total of 2 layers of tortillas. I tore the 5th tortilla into pieces to cover the exposed edges after the 2 tortillas were laid for each layer.  I used fat free refried beans. I will make it again.  It is easy and filling.

text:
I made some modifications, nothing major though....I halved the recipe (which still made enough for leftovers!) and rather than a "pie", I made it into more of a lasagna in a 9"x13" pan, and I cut the tortillas to fit the pan entirely.  As far as the actual ingredients go, I kept them basically the same, except I added cumin, red pepper flakes, and chili powder to the meat mixture while it was browning.  Fantastic!  Even my kids devoured it, and neither of them like olives.  I will be making this again!

I have made this twice - once for work and again for a gathering of friends.  Everyone was asking for the recipe.  The first try of the recipe, I thought was slightly bland (I had gotten the original taco sauce and original Rotel). This really changed the flavor, but I would recommend them both.

text:
Excellant casserole!  If I was making for just myself, I would definitely kick up the spice scale.  My wife can not tolerate "spicy" though, and by making according to the recipe was mild enough for her.  Only changes, I omitted the olives(don't like them), added a tablespoon of cumin, and layered bottom of dish with crushed tortilla chips and shredded cheddar cheese(instead of colby).  I also topped the dish with the crushed tortilla chips & cheese.  Try some Franks Chili & lime Red Hot on top with sour cream smeared on. YUM!

country:
None
text:
Definitely half this recipe if you're not cooking for a huge crowd! haha.. I half it (thankfully), and it's still way too much for my family of three. However, it is a tasty dinner. I followed someone's suggestion of spreading some beans on the tortillas. I'm not sure if it makes any difference at all, but it tastes good that way. Word of caution, though - be sure to spread some of the beef/bean mixture in the bottom of the pan before putting a layer of tortillas in! I learned this the hard way - you'll end up with crispy tortillas :)  Also, to turn down the heat a little if you have kids, you can use mild salsa in place of the taco sauce and use the mild Rotel - still tastes great!

None
text:
Delicious! Made a few minor tweakings, such as using ground turkey instead of ground beef, omitted the olives and the extra can of diced chiles (to keep it more friendly for my kids), used only 8 oz. of taco sauce, and Monterey Jack/Colby cheese blend. Make sure to have a circular, deep casserole dish on hand to bake this so that it doesn't tip or fall over as you build it. I made one with about 6-8 layers, and that fed 4 adults (with seconds and leftovers) and two small kids and still had half the meat/bean mixture left over to freeze for the next time I make it. Awesome recipe--a definite must try! Thanks!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Nice comfort food.  Even better warmed up the next day.  We didn't find it spicy at all.  I added a packet of Taco Bell taco seasoning to the meat because it tasted too bland before I baked it.  I also used just one can of refried beans, as someone else had suggested, and a two cup bag of Mexiblend cheese.  I topped it with a dollop of lite sour cream, and served it with a salad of shredded lettuce, chopped cilantro, fresh tomatoes and red onion, then kind of mixed it all together.  Really nice this way!  I will make this again and will try corn tortillas for a different taste.  All in all, worth a try if you're looking for a different use for ground beef.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was awesome! Very filling. Total comfort food. We're cheese lovers so we added more cheese to the layers. Exchanged the taco sauce for enchilada sauce-good move. I didn't think it was too spicy. We live in Ca. so we eat a lot of authentic Mexican food-guess we're used to it. Be sure to buy enough tortillas. My husband thought we'd run out so he only put two on the bottom two layers.  The tortillas layers really need to completely cover the baking pan. I'd recommend three and a half to four a layer to make a complete layer in the dish size recommended. In other words, don't skimp like we did! It makes a lot, so plenty of left overs.

text:
This recipe was pretty good. Here's how I think it could be improved: (1) More cheese!  (2) Higher meat to refried beans ratio. It seemed a little mushy. (3) Use lasagna noodles instead of tortillas, unless you like really mushy casserole. (4) Did I mention more cheese? (5) Add some taco seasoning to the meat mixture for a little more flavor.  Still, the recipe *was* pretty good just as it is.

This recipe is a delicious potluck dish and tastes even better the next day.  I like to make it in a round casserole dish and cut into it just like a pie! text:
I'm really not sure why everyone raves about this?  My brother-in-law commented that it reminds him of something you'd get at Taco Bell, and that pretty much sums it up for me, too.  The flavor is OK, just nothing special.  Much better over fresh lettuce and with extra sauce or salsa on top, and I wish I'd have skipped the green chilis and added some Jalapenos instead -- they would have looked nice on the top I bet.  This is a nice basic recipe, probably really good for kids or picky eaters, but too bland for my taste.

country:
None
text:
The most requested meal at our house.  Even the little ones can't get enough. I did make a few changes, which I thought enhanced the already wonderful flavor. First, I used corn tortillas instead of flour.  I also added some corn to the meat mixture, along with some taco seasoning, and cumin, and added a layer of spanish rice. I omitted the black olives (as I don't care for them) and I used a 4 cheese mexican blend instead of colby, and put chopped green onions on top layer. Great on a plate of lettuce and topped with sour cream.  Can't get much better than this!!!

text:
Was looking for a different Mexican casserole from the usual, and this fit the bill.  I substituted salsa and tomato sauce in the meat mixture and left out the olives just because of what I had on hand.  Also used corn tortillas, as that's all I had too.  I alternated the meat mixture, topping with longhorn cheese, with the beans mixed with some sour cream and jack cheese, to stretch it out to make a large casserole with what I had.  It was wonderful and everyone was happy.

text:
The meat mixture almost didn't make it into the casserole dish.  I am usually pretty disciplined about ignoring the temptation to nibble while cooking, but with this meat mixture, one bite led to another and--well, you know how that can go!  This meat mixture could be used for SO many other recipe ideas, including straight-- as a soup or goulash type dish.  Man, it was SO good.  Then, with everything else added, it came out spectacularly.  After a blooming onion for an appetizer, this Burrito Pie tasted great.  I highly recommend it.  As others recommended, I used one can of refried beans and one can of black beans.  I used medium taco sauce.  Next time I may take the plunge with HOT sauce!

Over all this was a tasty recipe.  I liked it and so did my children.  I was a little hesitant on the green chiles.  But in the end was glad I used the chiles.  Definately not too spicey. As for my husband he gave it the 4 star rating because I make my own similar recipe (called enchilada casserole) to this one and mine (he says) is much better.  I have to say I do like my original recipe better too but this one is nice for a change.

The recipe itself was somewhat bland.  Not spicy at all - and I'm pregnant!  I added a couple of jalapenos and will use Hot taco sauce next time. text:
I was very disappointed in this, although my husband liked it. I used ground turkey (which wasn't the problem), whole pinto beans, a can of Rotel, sharp cheddar and only three tortillas.  I simply ran out of room in my dish (somehow I missed that you were to use a 4 quart casserole dish and I used a 10" pie pan instead BUT I had cut the recipe in half). If I were to make this again I wouldn't use Rotel and I would stick to using refried beans. I would mix the beans and the meat mixture as well. Too many "improvements" ruined this one for me. Thankfully, my husband is gracious and loves Mexican food. He had no complaints.

text:
My son and I liked this. (My daughter wasn't crazy about it, but the neighbor lady had already fed her pizza. That was probably a factor.)
I think this a great basic recipe that is easy to change and add to. I halved the recipe for the three of us and it was more than enough. Next time, I'll leave out the refried beans - I thought they made the meat sauce too mushy. I served it with sour cream and extra taco sauce drizzled on the top.
Using the amount of peppers the recipe calls for, didn't make this too spicy for us (we don't like hot-hot foods), so don't be afraid to give it a try.

text:
The recipe didn’t call for any seasonings.  I added my own and eyeballed it with cumin, pepper, chili seasoning, oregano, and Goya adobo seasoning. I used corn tortillas for an authentic taste.  I love flour tortillas usually.  I layered a few tortillas as one previous reviewer suggested.  It came out pretty good but don’t put any tortillas on top or they’ll crisp up.  I would make again for myself but I don’t think it looks good enough to serve a guy-friend.

text:
I used a deep dish 13 x 9 lasagna baking dish and it all fit perfectly.  I cooked the ingredients in a dutch oven which plenty of room for all the ingredients  and made mixing easy.  I have a deep 12 " skillet and this recipe would have been too much for it.   I  used one can of refried beans with jalapeños which I mixed into the mean mixture. The other can of traditional beans I spread on the tortillas as other have.  Having that stand alone flavor was nice. The extra kick was perfect.  My teenage kids loved it. Tastes much like a fast food meat, been and cheese burrito. Makes great left overs. Will definitely make again. Will try using one can of whole black beans.

userID:

Display Name:
Jkaeekjj
isPro:

9

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674140.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this vegetarian by reconstituting 2.5 cups of TVP with 1/4 cup of soy sauce and hot water to cover. Sautéed an onion until lightly browned and added the typical Mexican cuisine spices, TVP and a can of mixed beans (rinsed). Once the TVP was browned, I added a can of Rotel and a can of enchilada sauce to thicken. I heated the tortillas on a cast iron pan until slightly crisp, and then layered the casserole with more enchilada sauce in a 13x9 baking dish. I only used about a half bag of shredded queso cheese for the entire thing since I don’t like too much cheese. Turned out great, everyone had a second helping. Nice change from tacos. Thanks!

text:
Will definitely make this again. The top 5 helpful reviews were spot on. Simmer on med - med/high for at least 15-20 more minutes to meld mo mo betta. Spread spicy beans on tortillas (I always use large white corn) & add a little to mixture to stiffen & place face down. Taco sauce was a little over-bearing so Ill use a little less next time. I used 3 bags of shredded cheese (don't  judge me!) Mexican blend/sharp cheddar/pepper jack. Last but not least: a small amount (very small) of fresh jalapeno & habenero pepper for taste. Divinity!

text:
Thank you for a great recipe that is delicious, easy and IMO very economical.  Halved the recipe as only cooking for 2 and still had 4 pieces left to freeze for a few more meals.  Used a 9x9 pan and simply cut the tortillas (2 thick and 4 total per layer) in half then lined the straight ends to the side of the pan with the curved tortilla edges overlapping in the middle. Produced solid layers easy to serve and freeze for later.

text:
We loved this although I had to make a few changes because I was short of supplies. I didn’t have taco sauce so I added the taco seasoning from this site along with the tomatoes and chilis. As written allow the sauce to simmer for a while to get the best out of the flavours.  I also only used 1 pound of ground beef. This made enough to feed 4 people.  I didn’t add the refried beans to the mixture instead I spread the refried beans onto the tortilla then put the meat, then cheese. I wasn’t able to layer all 12 tortillas. It was thick enough at 5. I would recommend giving this recipe a try. It is really delicious.

text:
FAMILY FAVORITE! We call this burrito casserole because we always double the recipe and bake it in a 9x13 pan.  We love the original recipe but over the years we have made a couple minor changes.  We don't add the salsa because the Rotel chile tomatoes have plenty of spice.  We also add thinly sliced tortillas on the top.  They brown on top of the cheese and add a little crunchy texture.  My kids always beg for the piece with extra crunchies.  You must try.

text:
We loved this!  It goes together easily and uses simple ingredients that are easily found.  While this was in the oven I tossed a quick salad and dinner was ready in no time. This is a great basic "Mexican" recipe that can be tweaked to suit individual tastes and still come out amazing.   I chose to substitute red enchilada sauce for the taco sauce because of the flavor differences and also added pepper jack and queso cheeses as well.  Be sure to give this time to set up after removing from the oven, just like lasagna. It's easier to serve and makes a better presentation.  This is a winner!

text:
Hubby loved this meal!  I took the advice of some of the other reviewers and toasted the tortillas and spread the refried beans on one side of them before assembly.  I used Mrs Dash taco seasoning, 1 tbsp. tapioca flour, and a little water to the meat/tomato mixture and simmered for 20 min.  Also sprinkled  roasted sweet corn after each meat layer which complimented the spices and heat from the chiles.  Served with homemade guac and salsa on the side. Yummy!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was so darned good! Like several other reviewers suggested, I definitely had to add (1/2 tsp) kosher salt and (1/4 tsp) ground pepper while browning the meat for an all-around balanced flavor. I halved this recipe, as there were only four of us that night, but ended up with enough leftovers for five people the next night! I served with shredded lettuce and halved cherry tomatoes on the side. I also included sour cream "laced with" a bit of adobe sauce to add a bit more zing for an amazing topping! Great "pie"!! 
P.s. I feel the salt and pepper is a must in most of my savory cooking, but I know some people can't/don't eat salt...so  I still give this recipe 5 stars because to me those two staple ingredients are just a given tweak ;) Thanks for recipe!!

I made this for a party last night and it was a huge hit.  I followed other reviewers suggestions and layered the refried beans on top of the beef, with layers of: beef, refried beans, cheese, 2 layers of burrito style (thicker) tortilla shells, and then repeated this as the directions noted.  I placed it in a deep stoneware 9x13 pan and it filled it nearly to the top.  I had expected to bring home most of it from the party as it was a small gathering with other food but I was wrong!

I halved the recipe for our family of three. I made it but simplified it a little to suit ingredients on hand. I used a packet of taco sauce from a kit and added salsa to the rest of the meat mixture. I also added cumin and paprika to the meat while browning. Served with lettuce and sour cream with a side of corn. Yum!

I love this kind of recipe. Tasty,  hearty and feeds a lot! Ok, I was  a little concerned about the flour tortillas since they have so little flavor compared to the corn ones. userID:
4735759
Display Name:
Malory Truman
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3467393.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just made this for the first time last night, and we enjoyed it very much. I made some changes that I think improved it. I followed the suggestions of a few reviewers -- I used 2 flour tortillas between the layers, AND I pan-fried them (dry in a non-stick skillet). I also spread the refried beans on the bottom of the lower tortilla instead of adding them to the meat mixture. I also added a small can of whole kernel corn to the meat mixture. My 12-year-old dislikes chunks of tomato, so I used a smooth picante sauce in place of the diced tomato, and I used a can of tomato sauce, + a tsp each of cumin and chili powder in place of the taco sauce, because commercial taco sauce has way too much sodium & is way too chemical-y for me. Oh, and I also added a tsp each of cinnamon and unsweetened cocoa, which made it really rich, and deepened the flavor. 

I used a pound & a half of ground beef & cooked the whole thing in a large souffle dish. It towered above the sides, so I placed it on a cookie sheet before putting it in the oven, and I'm really glad I did. Cooking was a little messy and cutting it was uber-messy. It oozed all over the place, but I saved the overflow & I'm eating it on a leftover baked potato for lunch today. This was a delicious dish, and I will certainly make it again (with my modifications).

text:
Absolutely will be making AGAIN!
This meal is wonderfully flavorful!  I made it with no additions or alterations except for  I accidentally misread ingredient list and only used 8 oz taco sauce. Next time I will use the required amount.  I drained all ingredients that had liquid (except for taco sauce) because of other reviews indicating it was soggy.  When it came out of the oven it was perfect and not even slightly soggy.  This dish  was an easy recipe to make.  It would be extremely simple to divide in half as you make it and freeze.  It makes a ton!  As another reviewer stated, be sure to use an extra large skillet or a dutch oven.  It makes stirring easier.  My husband kept raving about how good it was and how tasty. He had three helpings.  We will keep this in our "favorites" and I plan to make it frequently.

text:
I'm sure I would have liked this recipe as is, but I made changes due to what I had on hand and because my husband prefers corn over flour tortillas. I too added taco seasoning, about half a packet. I used chili beans instead of refried beans cause that's what I had in the cabinet. Used corn tortillas instead of flour.  I think because I didn't use refried beans the mix wasn't as thick as it would've been, so I added some flour after it simmered to thicken it up. My family enjoyed it very much.

Latino style Lasagna with a kick! Family loved it, my picky hubby had seconds and he doesn't even like "Mexican"style food. saving it to my recipe box to make again. text:
I made this with one pound ground beef and one pound ground turkey to lighten up the meat a bit.  I also added taco seasoning and used chunky salsa instead of  taco sauce.  I cooked the meat for a while, to cook out most of the liquid.  I did not want my dish to be too soggy.  I used another reviewers advice and layered two layers of flour tortillas, to help avoid any sogginess.  I layered just like a lasagne (meat, two layers tortillas, thin layer of refried beans, then cheese).  This turned out wonderful , everyone loved it and I can not wait to make again!

text:
Super delicious-- and even better the next day!

Next time around  I think I might add jalapenos or something else to spice it up a little more. I like spicy, and although this was good, the spice wasn't enough for me.

As happywife05 said, you should also use more tortillas per layer. The beans and sauce do tend to soak into the tortillas and cause it to have a very soft and saturated texture.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe according to KathiMC's instructions, with 3 exceptions:  I cut the recipe in half to match our family of 4's usual appetite, therefore making two burrito pies of 6" diameter.  Second, I added 16 oz of salsa to the meat sauce, along with the taco sauce.  Third, I kept meat sauce and beans separate as suggested by another  reviewer.  I followed the suggestion of spreading the refried beans on the bottom of each tortilla layer.  That said, I was delighted by my family's enjoyment of this recipe!  I got complements when the kids got home from school and smelled the kitchen aroma while the  burrito pies were baking!  Not a drop was left on anyone's plate.  My family gave this an "8 thumbs" rating.  I will definitely be making this recipe again soon!  Thanks for sharing, KathiMC!

Either way this turned out great and I'd definitely make it again, just with half of the ingredients.

text:
This recipe was easy and really good.  
I used half of all ingredients and it filled a 11X8 pan. I served 3 people with it and had a lot left over! 

I utilized the suggestions from other posts when it came to the beans.  I layered beans in a tortilla and then put another tortilla on top.  Then, I slathered on another layer on the tortilla piece that I laid down on the meat mix.  It truly did taste like a Mexican pizza at Taco Bell!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/3054.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I prepared the meat filling in my 5.5 Le Creuset French Oven. I seasoned the meat with chili powder, garlic salt and ground pepper. I used mild taco sauce, fat free refried beans, and four whole wheat flour tortillas for each tortilla layer (total of 8 tortillas). This was baked in a 9X13 foil pan. I was able to fit most of the meat filling in that pan. I only had about 1 cup of filling leftover. Once ready to serve, I topped with fat free plain Greek yogurt (instead of sour cream) and served with a side salad. This makes about 8 adult sized servings. I would serve with tortilla chips and guacamole. Very easy and tasty recipe.

text:
This was a huge hit with the family.  My wife is not a big fan of spicy food, so I toned it down a bit by cutting out the green chiles and using a jar of Ortega mild taco sauce.  Left the Rotel in though for a little zip.  Followed others' advice and spread refried beans on tortillas instead of mixing in with meat mixture.  Otherwise, followed the recipe and it was muy excellente!!  Made it in a 9x13 glass pan and it could have used a little more meat for my liking.  Maybe a half pound or so.  It was just as good left over two days later, so no need to freeze any.

text:
This dish was really good. I followed the suggestion of some other reviewers and didn't mix the beans with the meat mixture. I spread the beans over the bottom of the tortillas as I layered to create a "buffer", and added onion powder, cinnamon, cumin and lots of chili powder to the ground beef since I didn't have ready-made taco seasoning on hand. It turned out great! Definitely adding this to my short list of go-to dinners. Like some other reviewers said, the recipe does make a lot, so plan on using more cheese than the recipe indicates. I went through 1 8-oz bag and got halfway through another one before I finished assembling.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Overall a great, easy comfort food recipe.  I agree with some of the reviews stating that it becomes a one-textured somewhat mushy meal.  If I was ordering this in a restaurant I could see this being disappointing because you expect a little more effort/creativity, but I don't mind this at home when we are looking for a easy, satisfying meal.  If I were going to try and jazz this up I would use ground chorizo instead of ground beef and keep the meat separate from everything else, then layer like so....bean mixture on bottom, tortillas, meat mixture and cheese, tortillas, bean mixture, tortillas, meat and cheese, tortillas, etc.  If you make this in a deep 9" pie dish you can just use burrito size tortilla's, 2 per layer and have a nicely layered lasagna effect.  We fit all the ingredients into one deep pie dish.

Display Name:
sunshinedays

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband and I loved this recipe. This is of particular note because my husband actually looked at me and said, "This is really good," whereas, his usually description for everything is "It's okay." 

I did as others recommended and spread the beans on the bottom side of the tortillas. I also used mild taco sauce and a mild can of tomatoes with green chilies. There was zero spice, so in the future I plan to use medium taco sauce and/or the original (rather than mild) diced tomatoes with green chilies. I also drained the liquid from the tomatoes and what I could from the can of green chilies. Before putting everything in the pan, I tasted the meat mixture, and did think it could use a little more flavor, so I liberally sprinkled garlic and onion powder and a just a bit of cumin then mixed well. I cooked it in a 9 X 13 cake pan in the order of meat, tortilla, cheese, meat, 2 layered tortillas, then meat (there wasn't much meat left at this point). During the last 10 minutes of cooking, I sprinkled cheese on top. Will definitely be making again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband started making something similar to this a while ago from a recipe coming with a brand of Mexican food. My husband also does not like ‘beans’ - most any kind of beans. I also have vegetarian friends. I make ‘Spanish Rice’ which is basically rice made with tomatoes or salsa substituting half water called for making regular rice. I use Spanish rice instead of refried beans for my husband. For those who do not eat beef – I use the rice again as a layer with beans. Another thing I also do just for the variety of color, with my refried beans I add some black beans. I add taco seasoning to ground beef after it has been drained of fat, and add a little salsa or tomatoes.  I have never used more than one layer of tortilla shell – but will the next time to see how it works. I have used low calorie whole wheat tortilla shells that have held up very well. Depending on what I have on hand – I layer onions, sweet peppers, poblanos and other mild peppers – use smaller amounts of hotter peppers – accept for those who like hot – (husband DOES like hot!)

2755581
Display Name:
Snercute

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We loved this recipe - although I did not follow the recipe exact.  I omitted the refried beans, using black beans in place.  I cooked the hamburger, added 2 tsps taco seasoning and about 1/4 cup taco sauce and 1 can of diced tomatoes (draining the juice).  Allowed mixture to simmer about 25 minutes.  I placed two flour tortillas in the bottom of the casserole dish (used 12 inch flour tortillas that I folded in half and cut into 10 inch diameter to fit casserole dish), layered hamburger, shredded cheese, black beans, sliced olives and sliced jalapeno's, placed two more cut tortillas and repeated the shredded cheese, black beans, sliced olives and sliced jalapeno's 4 times.  Last layer I cut up the 'rings' (remains from the cut up flour tortillas), placed them on top and layered with remaining shredded cheese.  Baked for 30 minutes at 350.  It was GREAT !!  Will definitely fix again

text:
I used less meat & added a can of beans. My family is used to that, so it's fine for us! I don't keep taco sauce on hand, but have salsa. I still wanted the taco sauce consistency, so I just blended the salsa up for a second in my mini processor. I was lazy tonight & used dehydrated onion & garlic in the meat.  I used the suggestion of another reviewer & made the tortilla layers 2 thick so it wouldn't get too mushy. That was actually perfect & I don't think we would have liked it as much without the extra tortillas.  I also added a cup of sour cream to the meat mixture.  I have another recipe that is very similar to this one, & the sour cream gives it a good little twang!  I used rotel tomatoes & combined with the chili peppers & salsa it was quite spicy! I thought the perfect amount! It was very very good, a definite keeper recipe for us!

Good but I changed by only using 1 pound hamburger and 1 pound Jimmy Dean Hot Sausage. Gives it a little more bit. I also cut the juice in the can of tomatoes and added about the same amount in Old El Paso Enchallata Sause. I make a simular filling but try to keep it thicker, then lay out a tortilla and fill with 2 teaspoons grated cheese and 2 tablespoons of filling. Roll the tortilla and lay in casserole dish. Pour enchalla sause over all, bake for 15 minutes at 350 and sprinkle more grated cheese over top.

text:
pretty good! I've made this recipe twice now. As written, I give recipe is 4 stars. With the reviews and/or recommendations of fellow "AR'ers", the dish came out a 5 star. Before laying the tortilla layer, I lightly toasted the the tortillas on an open flame. This gave the tortillas more flavor and a tad bit of chewiness.  I also went ahead and made the tortilla layer 2 tortillas thick. Doing those two steps made a big difference in the quality of meal. *** Tip: do not simmer your meat-bean mixture to long or the pie will become dry after baking it!***
Review:

userID:
6964855
Display Name:
wslazyk
isPro:
False

1

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674152.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This wasn't hard to make at all and my family loved it.  Both daughters asked for the recipe.

However, I did make changes. Instead of using a 16 oz jar of taco sauce and adding green chili peppers and diced tomatoes, I just use a 24 oz jar of chunky salsa.  The other change was to use cheddar cheese instead of Colby because that's what we had in the frig.

I also took the advice of several people who commented on the recipe and did the following:
 - Let the meat, onions, garlic and salsa simmer for 30-40 minutes to better infuse the flavor in the meat
 - Don't add the refried beans to the meat.  Instead spread the refried beans on the tortillas before layering them in the pan
 - The recipe calls to lay a single layer flour tortillas.  I used several tortillas to form a thicker layer.

text:
This is such a beautiful dish -- I wanted so much to really love it, but it was just "okay" to us. I used 2 tortillas per layer, as per others' suggestion, and used Taco Seasoning 1 on this site, which I really like, BTW. I also added Queso Fresco cheese, sour cream, and cilantro.  I can't put my finger on why, maybe too many refried beans (and I LOVE bean burritos), but I simply did not enjoy it after 6 or 7 bites, so I probably won't be making this one again. *************
UPDATE ***** Okay, so I've changed this from 3 to 4 stars, after talking to my son who cooks and DID like it. He didn't know there were beans IN it, so that's not the issue. We decided that it probably had to much taco seasoning in it, which is not even in the original recipe. Next time I'll cut it in half.  More cayenne or pepper flakes and less chili powder, perhaps. I'm eating leftovers as I write, and I think it actually tastes BETTER today than a few days ago! Who'd a thought??

I made this last night for family and it was great!! Everyone raved about it and called it a "definite repeat" dinner. I made it exactly as the recipe called except for one small change (because my skillet was too small). Unfortunately, the beef, taco sace, chiles, and tomatoes filled my skilled to the brim, so I had to heat up the refried beans seperately. Then I layered it as beef mixture, cheese, then spread the beans on the tortilla and put it face down on the cheese. It worked out perfectly that way!  I would definitely recommend this to anyone! 5 stars!

userID:

Display Name:
melodee

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First off I halved this recipe because halving it still took up an 8x11 baking pan. Except I used a whole 4 oz can sliced black olives. Instead of the diced tomatoes I used 1 large fresh tomato chopped up because that's what I had on hand. I used an 8 oz bottle Ortega hot taco sauce and one can drained pinto beans, not refried. This recipe can be less time consuming if you brown the ground beef, add in 1 package taco seasoning and 1/2 cup water, then add the garlic, onion, olives, tomatoes, green chilis, taco sauce and beans altogether and let simmer over medium heat for 10 minutes. I sprayed the bottom of the baking dish with cooking spray and put a layer of meat mixture, a layer of colby jack cheese, and a "2-ply" layer of whole wheat tortillas. (4 tortillas total) then did another layer of meat and cheese and topped it off with plain monterrey jack cheese, popped in the oven for 10-15 mins and it came out wonderful. Top it with diced tomatoes and sour cream and shredded lettuce if you like. This got really great reviews from my family.

text:
This is a really good recipe as-is.  For me though, I prefer to use it as a base to do my "throw-it-in-and-see-what-we-get" thing.  For my family, I skip the jar of taco sauce, add 1 1/4 (or so) cup of chunky salsa and 1 pkg of taco seasoning.  I also skip the cans of refried beans and packaged tortillas and use my own homemade variety. Because I make my tortillas a little thicker, I haven't had a problem with soggy tortillas or mush-mush.  Then, for garnish after it's done cooking, thrown on some sliced green onions and put out fresh lettuce, tomato and extra black olives as sides for my family to add to their plates.  We have this meal at least 3x's a month.  It's really quite good.

text:
This recipe is the BEST!  My family loves it and requests it often.  It is a very easy recipe to make.  We sometimes have it with mexican rice but mostly serve it alone.  I have added mexican rice along with the other ingredients and it is yummy mixed into the casserole.  I also use mexican seasoning in my ground chuck.  I cook the ground chuck, drain the grease, pour in 2 pkgs. Ortega or any mexican seasoning package, add 1 1/2 cup water.  Cook some of the water down, then add the other ingredients as directed.   My husband and girls just cannot get enough.  It makes enough to freeze half of the casserole to enjoy for another time.  I have also taken this to a sick neighbor who loves mexican food.  They loved it, too!

text:
This is AMAZING! I did change a few things: I browned 1 pound ground beef, partially drained a half a can of rotel and 1 can of kidney beans (I didn't have refried beans on hand) and put it into the cooked ground beef. Pour in 1 package of taco seasoning because I didn't have a jar of taco sauce. I sprinkled about 1 tablespoon of garlic salt and 1 teaspoon of onion powder in the meat mixture. My husband and I are not fans of onion so I didn't use any.. I also used cheddar cheese. I put a tortilla, the meat mixture then cheese and repeated. The second time I put an extra tortilla on top with cheese on it. It was GREAT! My husband raved over it and so did my neighbor who we invited over!!

text:
Great recipe.  I alter it greatly though now that I have made it a few times.  I use ground turkey verse beef.  We cut ground beef out of our diet over a year ago. I don't like spicy things, so the taco sauce is mild. I skip the black olives and green chili peppers.  I switch the canned diced tomatoes to one without peppers and with an Italian flavor to them.  And I have added enchilada sauce which really adds a boost. When cooking the turkey first - I add meat tenderizer, garlic powder, onion powder, worchestire sauce, and what ever else I am feeling.

text:
Wow! I wasn't sure what to expect with this recipe, but it's like a mexican lasagna.  It kind of tastes like a beef enchilada.  I bet this would taste great with shredded chicken.  I used Rotel with Habaneros and nixed the extra can of green chiles.  It was plenty spicy, but not overpowering.  I used burrito sized tortillas as they nearly cover the complete dish.  Layered two tortillas between fillings and next time may use 3.  My husband didn't look encouraged when I was making the meat filling mixture, but a good cook knows looks can be decieving.  It's the taste that matters.  This is a family hit and a keeper! Thanks for sharing!

text:
My family was skeptical when I was making this dish, but they are believers now! My husband and 3 of my 4 kids went back for seconds! I love trying a new dish and having success. The great thing about this dish is you can adjust the ingredients to your personal taste. I trimmed two sides of the tortilla and layered them in a casserole dish. I did use 2 tortillas per layer. Then I spread the refried beans on each layer,  added the meat, which I cooked in enchilada sauce because I didn't have taco sauce, then added a thick layer of cheddar cheese. I cooked it covered for 30 minutes and uncovered for another 10. Served with lettuce, tomatoes, black olives and sour cream on the side. It was delicious and held its shape! My kids did rename it mexican lasagna!

As per the guidelines of creating this dish, I found the step by step instructions to be perfect and I ended up with a fantastic looking and tasting casserole (pie).  I chose to use black beans (drained) instead of refried beans due to personal preference and I also added a layer of mexican rice after the first layer of tortillas, sauce and cheese.  Being someone who loves super spicy foods, I also added 2 sliced jalapenos to the meat mixture as well as including two cups of pepperjack cheese.  I have no doubt that this recipe would have been equally as fantastic as is, I just have a tendency to go for a bigger kick :-)

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674168.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband and I host a lunch get-together every Sunday for a bunch of his guy friends, and I made this today for them.  It was a big hit.  I made a few changes: 1) I used some leftover pulled BBQ pork meat instead of the ground beef mixture.  I know, not very Mexican, but I had a LOT leftover that I needed to use up and it went very very well with everything else. 2) I made the tortilla layers by making "sandwiches" out of the tortillas and beans (a couple big scoops of beans between two tortillas.)  This worked out very well since I thought the beans and meat mixed together may have been too thick, and the two tortillas per layer kept the casserole together without getting soggy. 3) I served the black olives on the side, along with various other toppings, since some of my guests don't like black olives. All in all, this was very quick and easy to make and very good.  Our guests loved it.

text:
I am so glad I tried this recipe and it was my first time. I brought it over for a potluck for my club's event and they loved it. It was funny, because we didn't have enough forks, so people were trying some crazy stuff to get some. If you are reading this review, BE SURE to check everyone else's reviews ESPECIALLY ones that give suggestions. I doubled the tortilla layer, so there was four stacks of two tortillas. Don't mix the refried beans with the meat mix. Leave the meat sitting in the taco sauce for about 30 min like how one of the previous reviews said. I did the meat-tortilla-bean-cheese-meat layering pattern. I think next time I do this dish I am going to add lettuce, guacamole, and sour cream. Thanks so much for sharing this recipe.
