text:
I thought this was really good after I changed it that's why I'm giving it 4 stars.  The whole family loved it.  First I did not mix the beans with the meat.  Instead I spread it on the tortillas, and placed the bean side down.  I also used some taco seasoning in the meat without extra water.  Even after draining the meat, and canned vegetables the meat mixture was still to runny.  May also leave the taco sauce out of the mix next time, but still add it in somewhere along the line.  With each tortilla layer I used 3 tortillas instead of one because it would have been to soggy.  Also, I used alot of extra cheese.  I'm not so sure about freezing this because it gets soggy easiliy.

country:
None
text:
This is a fantastic dish that freezes and reheats well, which is a must in my house for weekday nights.  I only cook for two right now, so I would definitely suggest cutting the amount of meat in half to 1 pound.  To that I added a can of diced tomatoes, a white/yellow onion chopped, most of a can of pinto beans (instead of refried), and at least one packet of taco seasoning mix.  That's your filling.  Use at least two flour tortillas per layer and finish with some cheese on top.  The best mexican rice I have found was by Goya (yellow rice, chicken flavored).

This is a good recipe and it makes a lot which is handy because I just froze most of it for future meals! I did what others mentioned by putting the beans on one side of the tortillas instead of mixing them in with the meat and it worked out well - it kind of gave it more a layering of flavors. I also added in a packet of taco seasoning mix to the meat which gave it good flavor. I didn't have a 4 quart casserole dish but I used my 3 quart one and it worked fine. It was at the brim but I got it all in there without overflowing. I'll make this again for sure. thanks!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/478131.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is pretty good and filling, and it's very easy to make! I scaled it down since I only have my husband and myself to feed, and I made a few changes.  I browned 1 lb. beef, drained, added taco seasoning and fiesta nacho cheese condensed soup instead of taco sauce.  I then stirred in a can of Rotel and a small can of sliced black olives (rinsed/drained) and let it simmer for a few minutes. I spread zesty jalapeno beans on 4 10-inch wheat tortillas and layered with the bean side down. The layers were thus: Meat mixture, 2 beany tortillas, cheese, meat mixture, 2 beany tortillas, and a final layer of cheese.  I baked it in a 9 X 13 casserole dish at the temperature/time indicated in the recipe.  We both liked it (even though we're not big fans of ground beef). I'll make it again probably.  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
Excellent!  I used ground turkey, whole wheat tortillas, and fat free refried beans.  After reading several reviews, I made the following changes: I divided the recipe between a pie pan and a springform pan and cut the tortillas to fit.  I used 8 tortillas, spread refried beans, then meat/tomato/sauce mixture and topped with cheese.  I don't think double-layering tortillas is necessary.  Served with shredded lettuce, chopped fresh tomatoes, sour cream and extra shredded cheese.  WONDERFUL mexican dinner!  It does take a bit of preparation time, but very good.

This was okay - I don't know if it was better than taco bowls but maybe worth another go.  I made a few changes . . . 1. I added a packet of taco seasoning (just the seasoning - no additional water) to the meat. 2. I also added a can of rinsed black beans and a can of drained sweet corn to the meat mixture. 3. I also added some peach salsa to the top before baking for some extra flavor. 4. Before serving I sprinkled some finely chopped cilantro for some extra color.

text:
Cut the recipe in half, did not have Rotel tomatoes, so used 1/2 can of petite diced; had no chilies, so diced some jarred jalapenoes; did not have 8" tortillas but had 5 burrito sized, so tore them into bite-sized pieces; added taco seasoning packet as suggested by others.  Made two layers, plus the bottom cover out of the sauce, which was a bit scarce at the end. DH enjoyed it.  I put plain yogurt over my serving, as sour cream sounded like a good addition and that was all I had.  Easy and pretty tasty.  Thanks for sharing.

text:
This was really good!! I did learn a few things that I will change. I didn't have enough salsa so I used taco seasoning with a little water and used what salsa I had, about 3 TBSP. (I did like the flavor the taco seasoning gave.)I also did a double layer of tortillas with the beans spread on the first layer. With my seasoning/salsa mixture it wasn't as moist as I would have liked; I'll do a single layer of tortillas the next time. I used a 9x13 pan which is too big for one recipe. You don't get the concentration of meat that I would have liked. My girls don't like black olives so I used them as a garnish,along with sour cream and shredded lettuce. Delicious!!

text:
This was a great meal!  Very filling and the entire family loved it!  We have a few picky eaters so I left out the olives, green chili's and just used a huge can of regular diced tomatoes.  I used a taco seasoning packet instead of the sauce and ended up having to blend a big can of beans in the blender to make the refried beans as I didn't have any on hand.  I also used whole wheat taco shells and it's the first time I haven't heard the kids complain about eating them!  You couldn't taste the difference.  Thanks for the great recipe . . . oh, I also almost doubled the cheese.  It was great!

This recipe was really good, and easy to put together.  I did make a few changes, just due to family preference.  I omitted the green chillies,  and used tomatoes ready for chili, instead of the ones with green chillies as my kids won't go for the hot stuff.  Instead, I threw in some frozen corn. text:
Excellent. I also added the taco seasoning. Dont add the extra water though. Just throw in th erotel tomatoes and let it simmer. Its best to spread the beans from the can onto the tortillas. Extra zing, put pickles japenos on the top prior to baking. Also I alternated with Quesadilla cheese and then put the Quesadilla cheese on the top. It has a great mexican flavor. I didnt add the taco sauce to the beef, i put it over each layer as assembled. When ready to eat, add guacamole, sour cream, and pico degallo. I also think spreading the beans on th eotrtillas keeps them from getting soggy. Enjoy

Wonderful! I am married to the one person on earth who doesn't care for Tex-Mex type stuff, and he really liked it. I halved the recipe and made some changes; omitted garlic and seasoned with a packet of taco seasoning, used green onion, and pinto beans instead of refried beans (don't care for refied beans).Also, since a two-year-old would be eating this, I used mild sauce, and regular diced tomatoes. Topped the pie with olives and sour cream, and served it with Mexicorn. I cooked the pie in a pie pan that fit the tortillas perfectly. It looked awesome and held together well. We all enjoyed it, and I can't wait to make it again. Thanks for sharing.

text:
UPDATE: Leftovers are just as good. It also made me think that the pie filling might be good on a Mexican pizza. Yum! Yummy, yum, yum!!! Made this for dinner tonight for my bf and I. We both really enjoyed it, even though the bf thought it to be too "beany" (but he doesn't care for beans that much anyways). I made only half the recipe since it was just for the two of us. I layered all ingredients as directed - except for omitting olives (neither my bf or I care for them) and using DOUBLE the amount of cheese (Mexican blend). My tortillas were slightly wider than the dish I used (a round Corning Ware casserole dish), but after pressing them down, they fit perfectly. I did find that the tortillas were a bit mushy (but not too bad) and that the pie needed to set for about 10 mintues before slicing in order to firm up. My bf was HUNGRY, so I served us right away and dealt with it. : ) I wonder if using two tortillas per layer would solve this problem??? Served with fiesta corn and tortilla chips for scooping! I think I might try the meat / bean mixture over nachos sometime. A very easy and delicious dish that I'm sure kids would love (just use mild chilies and taco sauce - I used the medium-heat variety). This one's going in my "keeper" file and replaces the Mexican Lasagna recipe by POPCKLGAL that I usually prepare. Thanks for sharing!

text:
Very easy to make and a great dish! I used the springform pan to make this seeing the tortillas fit perfect in it. Be careful when you go to take it out of the springform. I let the dish set for about 5 minutes then cut it in the pan and then released it. Otherwise I think it would all ooze out. I doubled the layers of tortillas and spead the beans on top as suggested in other reviews. Also used salsa instead of taco sauce. Just before I put on the top tortilla I spead sour cream over it then topped with more cheese. Will make again!! So easy to make it the way you want it!

userID:
2782886
Display Name:
BabyDsMama
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
1
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674152.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe for our Super Bowl Party and it was an unbelievable hit!  My mother-in-law (who is vegan/vegetarian) LOVED it, and so did my 15 year old nephew who hates "fake meat."  It was an all around success!
Like many of the others that reviewed this, I "messed with" the recipe a bit myself.  I used thicker, burrito-size tortillas and used vegetarian protein instead of ground beef.  Also, I didn't mix the beans into the "meat mixture," but layered them on the tortillas as previously suggested.  My Burrito Pie was layered: meat mixture, bean-side-down tortillas, cheese, bean-side-down tortillas, meat mixture, etc.  On the very top layer, I layered two tortillas and sprinkled extra cheese on top before baking.  This left a crispy top crust with a nice moist inside.
As other people have mentioned, definitely get more than 9 oz of cheese.  I used 16 oz.
I highly recommend this recipe.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2008-02-05T10:00:37.05

hubby and i had this last night, and it was o-so-delectable. good way to get me to eat refried beans, seeing as i hate them, but unnoticable in this!! :D hubby said would have like it to have crunched tortilla chips instead, so next time i will make half and half. simmered all the spices for 30 min (really lets it all blend) and forgot salsa/taco sauce, but had some mild sauce taco packets on hand, lol, so used about 15. :D i also added mexican rice already cooked, so my layers were as follows:
meat, rice, cheese, beans on tortillas, xtra tortillas, ect...

Display Name:
rookiechef
isPro:

146
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for the first time last night and my family loved it; it was even better today as leftovers!  I made one 9x11 casserole and one pie casserole dish (to freeze).  I was going to try and make 3 pie casserole dishes, but it seemed there wouldn't be enough of the meat mixture to layer all 3 dishes.  I made the following changes based on reviews: 1) I pan friend the tortillas for more texture.  2) I spread the refried beans between two tortillas per layer. 3) I added one full packet of taco seasoning to the meat. I somehow ended up with the tortillas on top, so I just top it with cheese, and another can of sliced olives, then I baked it covered so it wouldn't dry out.  It came out great. I may actually try mixing the refriend beans with the meat mixture next time to make it easier to assemble.

text:
I gave this recipe high ratings. My family loved it and it was something easy to make after a hard days work. I did like many people change up the recipe. I used 2 pounds of beef and seasoned it with garlic and onion powder and some old el paso taco seasoning. I left out the chilies and olives. I used a 14oz can of Del Monte tomatoes and zesty mild chilies. I used a pound of Mexican blend cheese in place of the Colby. After I browned the ground beef and sautéed the garlic and onion. I drained the grease then cooked the mixture in a bigger pot. I layered everything like in the recipe and cooked it about 20-25 minutes. I let it rest for about 10 minutes. Then I cut and served it with salsa, sour cream,and lettuce.

text:
Good base recipe. I made these changes. 1 lb of ground beef
1 tsp of fresh chopped garlic
1 can of stewed tomato
1 can of corn drained
1 packet of mckormick white chili mix
I had no green chilies (they are in the white chili mix)
When I layered with tortillas, I put one layer of refried beans, one layer of beef, one layer of uncle ben's ready rice (garden veg.) with fresh avocado slices. Keep layering and top with tortilla and fresh avocado slices.  Serve with side of sour cream, paul newmans mango salsa, and lettuce...yum yum.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yummmm!  This is a family favorite -- one that mom, hubby and all three kids look forward to eating.  It's also easy to make; reheats well and travels well.  The taco sauce you use, both brand and heat, makes a huge difference in this dish.  Mine always comes out a little different since I switch up sauces alot, but the results are always delicious.  If you're serving young kids or adults who can't handle spice, try using a mild sauce and eliminating the chiles as this dish can be quite spicy (which I love!)  I've made it with and without the beans and it's great either way.  You really can't go wrong with this one.  It's awesome!
Note:  Use a deep casserole where you can get at least three or four layers of tortillas.  Two few layers and it's a mushy mess.

This is way too good! We aren't huge fans of beans so I only used one can and it was still very tasty. I only used the recommended amount of flour tortilla's and it wasn't too soggy or anything. I think it may have to do with how you layer it. I also added a pinch of red pepper to spice it up a little since all of the ingredients I found were mild- I may add more next time because I love that spicy aftertaste! Great recipe!
Review:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good, but with a few changes.  I cook for my husband and I, and the original recipe said it served 16!  So, I used a pie plate to make this pie and it came out to be only about 4-5 layers.  I used ground turkey and mde it with some taco seasoning instead of taco sauce becuase that's what I had on hand.  It worked out well becuase the liquid from the tomatoes helped to dissolve it and I ommitted the water it calls for on the taco seasoning packet.  Because everything was so hot when I put it together, I only baked it for about 15 minutes and then I put it on broil for less than 5 minutes so that the cheese got brown and very bubbly.  We loved it.  VERY tasty.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I read the reviews and added taco seasoning to the meat, doubled on the tortilla layers, spread the refried beans onto the tortillas, used a 9X13 pan, cut the tortillas so they would fit, let the meat simmer for 30 minutes and even added jalapenos to the sauce. I did try putting tostitos chips on top then putting cheese over before putting in the oven. Don't do it, it makes it really hard to cut into. Overall it turned out very tasty and I’m giving it five stars; however, I’m not sure if just making burritos or tacos would have been just as good. I will make this again but not anytime soon.

country:
None
text:
I really enjoyed this recipe. However, I did make a change or two. I didn't have ground beef so I boiled 3 frozen chicken breasts and then shredded them into the pan with the onions and garlic. It didn't seem to make as much as others said it would, I think thats because I used less chicken. Also at the suggestion of another reviewer, I spread the beans on the underside of the tortilla instead of mixing them into the sauce, and I only used one can of beans. 3 out of 4 in my family loved this recipe. For something crunchy my husband ate it with nacho chips.

Absolutely awesome!!! I didn't add the extra can of peppers. I also used a 13X9 in. pan. Instead of colby, I used 1/2 mont. jack and 1/2 cheddar! This was a great combo! This worked great! The only other thing I did was add some of the taco seasoning to the meat. Our family will make this one frequently in the future!!!

text:
This really makes a lot of food!  I would rate this recipe as OK.  I took the advice of others and added a packet of taco seasoning mix.  The flavor of this dish was absolutely wonderful, but it didn't have a great texture.  It sort of ended up looking like a pile of mush, BUT to be fair, the meat mixture tasted great.  I think I would make this again, but I would substitute broken up taco shells or corn chips for the tortillas.  I would probably also only use 1 can of the refried beans.  Overall, a good recipe.  Thanks!  :)

text:
Very good.  Make sure you use a round casserole dish, not a rectangular baking pan.  A rectangle won't allow you to easily stack the tortillas.  I've made this a few times, and have only used about half the tortillas before I run out of sauce!  Also, I use Boca Crumbles instead of the ground beef.

text:
I've been making this recipe for about 3 years now.  My husband loves it and asks for it all the time.  I leave out the taco sauce - instead just cook the meat and add taco seasoning and water as the recipe says on the back of the seasoning package.  I also cook a bag of white rice and stir the cooked rice into the meat mixture - sometimes adding a little extra taco seasoning and water.  I layer refried beans on one half of the pie because my husband is not a fan. We love this dish.  The tortilla is never too soggy.  And the casserole is so much better the next day.

text:
I thought this recipe was really good.  My husband thought it was great, but would have been even better if it had something crunchy in it.  I modified this recipe as such: instead of adding the refried beans to the meat mixture, I added a can of mexican black beans with corn- San Antonia mix, as well as some chuncky salsa (left out the tomatoes) as well as adding a packet of taco seasoning per reviewer suggestion.  I also spread the refried beans to the tortillas.  It was a fun recipe to make as well, and easy to adapt to your own taste.

I had taken advice that the others had offered, I spread the beans on the tortilla layers and added the taco seasoning. I added Mild Taco Bell taco sauce (1/2 the amount required) with held from adding the tomatoes w/ green chilies, in stead I added Picante Medium - Chunky Salsa (16 oz). It was great, especially if you love spicy foods,it tasted pretty good as a left over(if you don't mind the look of eating wet dog food). My boyfriend didn't think it was the best, but his roommate loved it.

text:
This was very good, and very easy. The ingredients are mostly things I have on hand at all times. My husband was suspicious of it at first but when I told him what was in it, he tried it and was pleasantly surprised. It is a good family casserole, not something I would feed to company. It would also be really good for a Mexican-themed potluck. This is easy to make in advance and reheat. Also, if you let it set for a little while, it slices neatly. The only change was that I didn't put in the olives. No one in my family is that crazy about them. We will be seeing this one at the dinner table again, with some mixed vegetables or salad.

I made this recipe tonight and it was okay.  I also halved the recipe, but forgot to half the jar of salsa, but it didn't make much difference.  I added some crumbled tortilla chips as someone else did and I felt this made it better wiht some crunchiness to it.  Not sure what anyone is meaning by spicy.  This was so not spicy.  I left out the tomatoes.  Felt it would have been to "tomato-ey".  I also used two full flour tortillas as the base, meat, tortilla chips and cheese, then repeated this, though mixed up flour and corn tortillas since I ran out.  It still came out fine.  Wouldn't give it a 5 star rating.  Adding sour cream to the finished result made it better along with some taco sauce.   Will try again though.

Very very good.  I used a can of drained pinto beans in place of one can of refried beans.  The whole tomatoes/taco sauce/green chiles seemed inefficient so I tossed out all that and added a 16 oz. jar of salsa instead. Quite filling and made plenty.

text:
I LOVE mexican food but I thought it was just "okay" and my boyfriend said to make it only once a year.  I cut the recipe in half but ended up adding the whole jar of taco sauce because it was dry & there wasn't enough of the mix to spread.  I suggest if you do cut it in half to go ahead & use the entire jar of taco sauce, black olives, green chili's & diced tomatoes, but still only use 1 can of the refried beans.  Also use at least 8oz. of cheese.  It didn't seem very spicy to me at all.

Display Name:
Chris T

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe truly feeds a crowd.  I split the mixture into two casserole dishes for 2 meals.  It was really easy to make and tasted delicious.  My husband raved about it and I will definitely make this often.  I made a couple adjustments that really worked for our family.  I added a package of taco seasoning after the meat was browned and took off the extra grease.  I also was nervous about the "heat" of the recipe.  We love a good spicy dish and the ingredients looked harmless with the exception of the taco sauce.  I used half the jar of taco sauce, medium heat, and the rest medium heat salsa and it was just right..had a good kick, not overbearing for our taste.  I also found it needed more cheese than the 9oz Colby.  I used a 2c package of shredded Colby Jack and a 2c package of shredded cheddar. I may try it with ground chicken or turkey next time for a different twist. I can hardly wait to defrost the second serving for a future meal.  This recipe would be great for a pot luck.  Be sure to bring the recipe, because they will be asking for it.

country:
None
text:
A really good casserole, that is pretty easy to make, but does take a bit of time to get ready.  Next time I plan on making double the meat mixture and freezing some so that it can be put together quickly for dinner. I made some changes, used enchilada sauce instead of taco sauce and added an extra cup of salsa to the meat mixture to make it a bit "runnier".  Used one pound of low fat cheddar cheese, and low fat refried beans.  I have a really large casserole so I was able to make 2 "pies" or stacks of the tortillas which was then cut into 6ths.  I made one stack hotter by adding jalapenos for the more fiery people. It made 12 good sized meal portions, 16 portions would be kind of small.  Served with lettuce and low fat sour cream.  Will make it again. Thanks Kathi.

text:
This has become a favorite in our house.  I've made it several times cutting the recipe in half, but will begin making the full recipe so there will be more leftovers.

UPDATE: I've started substituting low carb soft tortillas in this recipe and don't notice any difference.  With the beans, this is still not a low carb recipe, but it does add even more fiber.  I like this best topped with shredded lettuce and diced tomatoes for some crunch and color.

text:
I made this recipe earlier tonight as I was making dinner.  I plan on having the burrito pie for lunch tomorrow and decided to make it ahead.  It was an easy recipe to follow.  I didn't have all the chilis and taco sauce the recipe called for so I made some substitutions:  To the ground meat mixture after browning, I added diced green peppers, a can of diced tomatoes (undrained), a small can of sliced olives (drained) and a packet of taco seasoning.  I used this as my meat mixture and followed the rest of the recipe.  I'm sure it will turn out since I stuck with the familiar mexican flavors.  When done, I plan on serving it with tortilla chips and a dollop of sour cream.  YUM!  I can't wait until lunch tomorrow!

My husband and I enjoyed this dish.  I substituted a can of Jalapeno Relish for the taco sauce, which brought the heat level up quite a bit.  I also used more cheese (shredded cheddar since that's what I had on hand) since I am a cheese lover.  I used pre-browned ground beef from my freezer, which meant that prep time was minimal-- I just simmered the ingredients about 10-12 minutes and then layered them in the casserole dish.

text:
Oh wow, this was awesome!  Let's see... changes I made... I halved the recipe and served it in a 9x13 inch pan.  I used 3/4 can of olives, 1/2 can of green chiles, 1/2 can tomatoes with green chiles, 3/4 can of refried beans, and more cheese than was called for.  I used about 3/4 package of taco seasoning mix and substituted about 8 oz. salsa for taco sauce.  Also sprinkled a bit of ground cumin in the meat mixture.  All of my seasonings were mild, as I have young kids.  Took this to a church pot-luck and the dish was scraped clean in no time!!  Thanks for sharing!!

My husband and I felt this was a good recipe.  I also added 1/2 pack of taco seasoning but next time I will use a whole pack because I felt it needed more flavor.  I also added about 1 cup of white rice leftover from chinese takeout.  We thought this was a good addition.  I used corn tortillas instead of white which I think gives it a more authentic flavor.  Used a 14.5 oz can of tomatoes instead of 10 oz.  I used 1 can of refired beans and 1 can of black beans, drained.  Added more cheese too.  Will make this again.

text:
This was great! I did do a few changes though. I reduced the amount of meat to 1 pound and used lean ground turkey instead. In place of the tomatoes I used a 16 oz. jar of medium salsa and an 8 oz. jar of taco sauce. I cut the amount of cheese to 6 oz and used pepperjack cheese instead. Nice and spicy and full of flavor. I've already printed the recipe out. Thanks for a tasty recipe!

text:
I made this yesterday and it was very good. But after reading all the reviews i decided i better listen to people and spice it up a bit. I added only 1/2 c extra spicy chunky salsa,threw in a packet of taco mix, and WHOA! WAS IT HOT. Be very careful people, it doesn't take much to put this one over the top. Thank goodness my family loves the hot stuff. I had to really souse mine with sour cream. Will definetly make again,WITH CAUTION!

text:
I changed this recipe slightly when I realized I didn't have enough stuff on hand to make the full recipe.  Instead of baking it in a casserole, I just used the meat mixture as my burrito filling.  After making the burritos, I arranged them in a baking dish, sprinkled a little cheese on them, and baked them til the cheese was melty.  SO SO GOOD!  I will definately make this again.  It would be great if you were having people over to "make their own burrito" night!
